인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Hello, the weather is nice today.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 안녕(安寧, peace) + 하세요(honorific). Related: 안녕히(peacefully). Common: 안녕하세요, 다녀오겠습니다(goodbye when leaving), 안녕히 계세요(goodbye to those staying).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: You're leaving already? Goodbye!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 안녕히(in peace) + 가세요(you go, honorific). Said to departing person. Pair with 안녕히 계세요 for those staying behind.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: I'll go first. Goodbye!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 안녕히(in peace) + 계세요(you stay, honorific). Said to person staying. Literally 'stay in peace.' Opposite of 안녕히 가세요.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Thank you for helping me.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Sino-Korean 感謝(gratitude) from 感(feel/sense) + 謝(thank). Related: 감사, 감지(感知, perception). Formal thanks for serious situations.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Thanks for the gift! I really like it.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Native Korean word of unknown etymology. Casual/friendly version of 감사합니다. Related: 고맙다(to be thankful). Common: 도움 고마워요(thanks for help).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: I'm sorry for being late.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Sino-Korean 罪(sin/fault) + 送(send). Formal apology. Related: 죄(crime), 송신(transmission). Use with elders/superiors.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Oh, sorry! I didn't see you.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Native Korean word. Casual apology. Related: 미안하다. Common in everyday situations with peers. Softer than 죄송합니다.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Don't worry, it's okay.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Native Korean. Incredibly versatile: 'it's okay,' 'I'm fine,' 'no thanks,' 'don't worry.' Related: 괜찮다. Essential for daily conversation.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Yes, that's right. I think so too.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Native Korean. Also used as a filler word (like 'uh-huh'). Related: 네가(you, subject). Common: 네, 그렇게 할게요(yes, I'll do that).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: No, I'm not a student.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 아니(no, native) + 요(polite). Polite form of 'no.' Related: 아니다(to not be), 아니면(otherwise). Casual: 아니(just no) or 아니야.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Just a moment, I'll be right there!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 잠깐(brief moment, native) + 만(only) + 요(polite). Literally 'just a brief moment.' Common: 잠깐, 이거 뭐예요?(hey, what's this?).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Excuse me, where is the restroom?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Sino-Korean 失禮(discourtesy) from 失(lose/lack) + 禮(courtesy). Formal 'excuse me.' Related: 실례, 예의(manners). Use when interrupting elders.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: What did you say? I couldn't hear well.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 뭐(what, native) + 라고(quotative) + 요(polite). 'What did you say?' Related: 뭐라고 했어요?(what did you say?). Polite request to repeat.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Yes, I understand. I'll do that.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 알(to know, native) + 겠(will/intention) + 어요(polite). Shows understanding. Related: 알다(to know). Formal: 알겠습니다(formal understanding).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: I don't know the meaning of this word.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 모르(to not know, native) + 겠(will) + 어요(polite). Softer than 몰라요. Related: 모르다(to not know). Common: 이 단어 뜻을 모르겠어요(I don't know this word's meaning).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: How do you do. Nice to meet you.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 만나(to meet, native) + 반갑(glad, native) + 습니다(formal). First-time greeting. Related: 만나다(to meet), 반갑다(to be glad). Often paired with a bow.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Today was fun. See you again!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 또(again, native) + 만나요(let's meet, casual). Friendly goodbye. Related: 또 봐요(see you again), 또 해요(do it again).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).english: how are you? / are you doing well?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: It's been a while! How are you?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 잘(well, native) + 지내다(to get by, native) + 요(polite). 'How are you doing?' Used when meeting someone after a long time.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Good morning! Did you sleep well?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 좋은(good) + 아침(morning, native) + 이에요(is). 'Good morning' less common than in English. Koreans often just say 안녕하세요.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: It's late. Good night.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 안녕히(peacefully) + 주무세요(sleep, honorific from 자다). Used with elders/parents. Related: 자다(to sleep), 주무시다(honorific sleep).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).english: good work / thanks for your effort
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Good work today. Get some good rest.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 수고(labor/effort) + 하셨어요(did, past honorific). 'Good work/thanks for effort.' Very common in Korean workplaces and daily life.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: You're welcome, it's nothing.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Sino-Korean 千萬(ten million) but used idiomatically. Literally 'ten million' but means 'you're welcome.' Related: 천(thousand), 만(ten thousand). More common: 아니에요(no, it's nothing).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Excuse me, how much is this?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 저(over there, native) + 기(demonstrative) + 요(polite). Get attention of waiter/stranger. Related: 저기(there), 여기(here). Very useful in restaurants.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Hello? Can you talk right now?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 여(lady) + 보(to see) + 세요(honorific). Only for phone calls. Never face-to-face. Related: 전화(phone), 통화(call).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: You passed the exam? Congratulations!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Sino-Korean 祝賀(congratulation) from 祝(wish) + 賀(celebrate). Related: 축하(celebration), 축하하다(to congratulate). Formal: 축하합니다.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Happy birthday! I prepared a gift.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 생일(birthday, native 생 + Sino 日) + 축하해요(congratulate). Koreans celebrate solar and lunar birthdays. Related: 생일 케이크(birthday cake).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example: 새해 복 많이 받으세요! 올해도 건강하세요.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Happy New Year! Stay healthy this year too.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 새해(new year, native) + 복(blessing, Sino 福) + 많이(much, native) + 받으세요(receive, honorific). Used for both Jan 1 and 설날(lunar new year).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Wow, this looks delicious! Thank you for the food.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 잘(well) + 먹겠습니다(will eat, formal). Gratitude before eating. Key Korean table manner. Related: 먹다(to eat), 준비해주다(to prepare).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Thank you for the meal. It was really delicious.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 잘(well) + 먹었습니다(ate, past formal). Gratitude after eating. Pair with 잘 먹겠습니다. Common: 정말 맛있었어요(it was really delicious).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Welcome! How many people?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 어서(quickly/promptly, native) + 오세요(come, honorific). Welcome greeting in shops/restaurants. Koreans hear this constantly when entering any business.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Long time no see! How have you been?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 오래(long, native) + ㄴ만(only) + 이에요(is). 'Long time no see.' Related: 오래간만이에요(alternative form). Used when meeting someone after months/years.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).english: anything new? / nothing special going on?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example: 요즘 별일 없어요? 잘 지내고 있어요?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Anything new lately? Are you doing well?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 별(star/special, native) + 일(work/matter, native) + 없어요(no). Casual greeting checking in. Asks 'anything special?' Related: 별로(not especially).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: It's raining a lot outside. Be careful!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 조심(caution, native) + 하세요(do, honorific). 'Be careful/take care.' Related: 조심하다(to be careful), 위험(danger). Shows concern for others.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).english: good luck / I wish you luck
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: You have an exam tomorrow? Good luck!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 행운(good luck, native) + 을(object) + 빌어요(pray). 'I wish you luck.' Related: 행운, 빌다(to pray). Used before important events.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).english: cheer up / hang in there / stay strong
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Even if it's hard, hang in there. It will work out.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 힘(strength, native) + 내다(to put out/exert, native) + 세요(honorific). 'Hang in there/stay strong.' Very common encouragement. Related: 힘내(cheer up).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example: 자, 다 같이 건배! 건강을 위하여!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Alright, cheers everyone! To our health!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Sino-Korean 乾杯 from 乾(dry) + 杯(cup). Used when clinking glasses. Related: 술(alcohol), 마시다(to drink). Common: 건강을 위하여(to our health).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: It's lunchtime, have you eaten?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 식사(meal, Sino-Korean 食事) + 하셨어요(did, past honorific). Traditional greeting. Shows care in Korean culture, not just asking literally.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).english: I'll be back / I'm heading out
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Mom, I'm heading out to school!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 다니다(to go around, native) + 어(come back) + 오겠습니다(will, formal). 'I'm heading out.' Staple phrase in Korean households.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: I'm home! School was fun today.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 다니다(go) + 어(come back) + 왔습니다(came, past formal). 'I'm home.' Counterpart to 다녀오겠습니다. Used in families.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: The door is open. Come in!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 들어(enter, native) + 오세요(you come, honorific). 'Come in/please enter.' Polite request form. Related: 들어오다(to come in).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).english: excuse me but / pardon me but
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Excuse me, but what is your name?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 실례(discourtesy) + 지만(but). 'Excuse me but/pardon me but.' Prefaces intrusive questions politely. More formal than 저기요.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Can you help me? Of course!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 물론(of course, native) + 이요(is). Polite 'of course.' Related: 물론이지(casual). Shows enthusiastic agreement. Common: 당연하지(obviously).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).english: I'll do that / sure, I will
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Please send it by tomorrow. Okay, I'll do that.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 그렇다(to be that way) + ㄹ(will) + 게요(I will). 'I'll do that/sure I will.' Polite agreement. Very natural in conversation.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).english: if it's okay with you / if you don't mind
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: If it's okay with you, shall I help?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 괜찮다(to be okay) + ㅂ(honorific conditional) + 으시면(if you, honorific). 'If it's okay with you.' Polite phrase before suggestions.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).english: please / I ask of you / I request
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: I'm counting on you. Please help me a lot.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Sino-Korean 附託 from 附(attach) + 託(entrust). 'Please/I request.' 잘 부탁합니다 is used when meeting someone new professionally.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: What is your name?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Native Korean word. Asking age is normal in Korea to determine politeness level. Related: 이름값(living up to one's name). Common: 이름이 뭐예요?(what's your name?).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I am American.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Humble/polite form of 'I.' Always use 저 with strangers/elders. Related: 저희(we, humble), 나(I, casual). Common in formal speech.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I like coffee.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Casual form of 'I.' Use only with close friends/younger people. Related: 나도(me too), 나한테(to me). Never with elders.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: How old are you? (polite)
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Native Korean word. Age determines politeness level in Korean. Related: 나이가 어떻게(how old?). Important for social hierarchy.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I am twenty-five years old.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Counter for age (years old). Use with native numbers: 한 살(1 year old), 두 살(2 years old). 몇 살(how old?). Related: 살다(to live).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: Which country are you from?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Native Korean word. 어느 나라(which country?)는 standard self-intro question. Related: 나라별(by country), 나라밖(abroad).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example: 한국에 온 지 일 년 됐어요.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: It's been one year since I came to Korea.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Korea. Sino-Korean 韓國. Full formal name: 대한민국(Republic of Korea). Related: 한국인(Korean person), 한국어(Korean language).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I came from America.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: America/United States. Sino-Korean 美國 shortened from 미합중국. Related: 미국인(American), 미국 사람(American person).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I like Japanese food.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Japan. Sino-Korean 日本. Related: 일본인(Japanese person), 일본어(Japanese language), 일본 음식(Japanese food).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I can speak a little Chinese.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: China. Sino-Korean 中國. Related: 중국인(Chinese person), 중국어(Chinese language), 중국 문화(Chinese culture).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: What is your job?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Sino-Korean 職業 from 職(occupation) + 業(business). Common self-intro topic. Related: 직장(workplace), 직원(employee).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I am a university student.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Sino-Korean 學生 from 學(study) + 生(person/life). Related: 학교(school), 학원(academy), 선생님(teacher), 대학생(college student).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I'm an office worker. I work at an IT company.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 회사(company) + 원(person/member). Very common in Korea. Related: 회사(company), 직원(employee), IT 회사(IT company).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: Teacher, which school do you teach at?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Teacher, also respectful title for doctors/lawyers/professionals. Related: 선생(teacher), 님(honorific suffix). Used formally in many contexts.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: My mother is a homemaker.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Housewife/homemaker. Sino-Korean 主婦 from 主(master) + 婦(woman). Related: 전업주부(full-time housewife). Gender-neutral in modern usage.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: The doctor prescribed medicine for me.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Doctor. Sino-Korean 醫師 from 醫(medicine) + 師(teacher). Related: 병원(hospital), 약(medicine), 의료(medical). Addressed as 의사 선생님.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: The nurse gave me a shot.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Nurse. Sino-Korean 看護 (care) + 사(person). Related: 병원(hospital), 간호(nursing), 주사(injection).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: The chef at this restaurant is really famous.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Chef/cook. 요리(cooking) + 사(person). Related: 요리하다(to cook), 식당(restaurant), 셰프(chef, English loanword).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: Who is your favorite singer?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Singer. 가(song, native) + 수(expert/person, Sino). Related: 노래(song), 콘서트(concert), K-pop 가수(K-pop singer).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I watched the drama that actor appeared in.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Actor/actress (same for male/female). Related: 영화배우(film actor), 드라마(drama), 출연하다(to appear). Used for both genders.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: Where do you live?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Where. Essential question word. 어디(where) + 에서(at/from) = 어디서(where?). Related: 어디든지(anywhere), 어디서나(anywhere).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: What are you doing?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: What. 뭐 is casual/spoken form of 무엇. Essential question word. Related: 뭔가(something), 뭔데(what is it?). Everyday speech uses 뭐.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: Who is that person?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Who. Changes to 누가 when used as subject. Related: 누가(who did it?), 누군가(someone), 누구든(anyone).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: Why are you learning Korean?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Why. Can sound confrontational if said forcefully. Related: 왜요?(why?), 왜냐면(because). Soften with 왜요? for politeness.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: How do you do this?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: How. Very versatile. 어떻게 지내세요?(How are you?) is a greeting. Related: 어떻게 되다(what happened?). Common everyday word.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: My hometown is Busan. The sea is beautiful there.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Hometown. Commonly asked during introductions. Related: 고향이 어디예요?(where's your hometown?). Koreans ask this as a standard question.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I got married last year. I'm very happy.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: To marry/get married. Native 결혼(marriage) + 하다(to do). Related: 결혼식(wedding ceremony), 미혼(single), 기혼(married).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example: 저는 아직 미혼이에요. 결혼할 생각은 없어요.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I'm still single. I have no plans to get married.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Single/unmarried. Sino-Korean 未婚 from 未(not yet) + 婚(marriage). Formal term used on forms. Related: 기혼(married), 결혼(marriage).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: Are you married or single?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Married. Sino-Korean 旣婚 from 旣(already) + 婚(marriage). Formal term for married status. Used on official forms.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: What was your major in college? Mine was economics.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Major/field of study/specialty. Sino-Korean 專攻 from 專(specialize) + 攻(study). Very common question in introductions. Related: 전공하다(to major in).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I graduated from university this year.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: To graduate. 졸업(graduation) + 하다(to do). Related: 졸업식(graduation ceremony), 졸업장(diploma). Common milestone in Korea.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: Do you have experience working in Korea?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Experience. Sino-Korean 經驗 from 經(experience) + 驗(verify). Related: 경험하다(to experience), 경험자(experienced person). Used in interviews.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I have a lot of interest in Korean culture.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Interest/concern. Sino-Korean 關心 from 關(concern) + 心(heart/mind). Common: 관심이 있다(to be interested), 관심이 없다(not interested).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example: 제 꿈은 한국어 선생님이 되는 거예요.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: My dream is to become a Korean language teacher.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Dream. Native Korean word. Used for both sleeping dreams and life aspirations. Related: 꿈을 꾸다(to have a dream), 꿈을 이루다(to achieve a dream).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: My personality is on the quiet side.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Personality/character. Sino-Korean 性格 from 性(nature) + 格(character). Often asked in introductions. Related: 성격이 좋다(good personality).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example: 저는 외향적이라서 사람 만나는 걸 좋아해요.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I'm extroverted, so I like meeting people.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Extroverted/outgoing. Sino-Korean 外向的 from 外(outside) + 向(direction). Opposite of 내성적. Related: 사람 만나기(meeting people).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example: 저는 좀 내성적이에요. 혼자 있는 게 편해요.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I'm a bit introverted. I'm comfortable being alone.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Introverted/reserved. Sino-Korean 内省的. Not negative in Korean culture. Related: 혼자(alone), 조용한(quiet), 외향적(extroverted).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example: 제 특기는 요리예요. 한식을 잘 만들어요.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: My special skill is cooking. I'm good at making Korean food.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Special skill/talent. Sino-Korean 特技 from 特(special) + 技(skill). Common on resumes. Related: 특기가 뭐예요?(what's your talent?). Often asked.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: What's your blood type? I'm type A.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Blood type. Sino-Korean 血液型. Koreans believe blood type reflects personality (A/B/O/AB types). Common icebreaker question.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: My nickname is 'teddy bear.' My friends call me that.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Nickname. 별(star/special) + 명(name). Koreans frequently use nicknames. Related: 별명이 뭐예요?(what's your nickname?). Fun icebreaker.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: One plus one is two.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: One (1). Sino-Korean 一. Used for dates, money, phone numbers, math. Related: 일월(January), 일 더하기 일(1+1).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: February is short.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Two (2). Sino-Korean 二. 이월(February) is 2nd month. Related: 이월, 이틀(2 days, native).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Please wait just three minutes.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Three (3). Sino-Korean 三. Used in 삼분(3 minutes), 삼월(March). Related: 삼각형(triangle), 삼(3).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Cherry blossoms bloom in April.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Four (4). Sino-Korean 四 but also means 'death' (死), so 4 is unlucky. Some buildings skip 4th floor. Related: 사월(April).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: It's five thousand won.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Five (5). Sino-Korean 五. Money uses Sino: 오천 원(5,000 won). Related: 오월(May), 오시간(5 hours).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: It rains a lot in June.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Six (6). Sino-Korean 六. 육월(June). Pronunciation: may shift to '뉵' before certain sounds. Related: 육월, 육십(60).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Seven times eight is fifty-six.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Seven (7). Sino-Korean 七. 칠월(July). Math uses Sino: 칠 곱하기 팔(7×8). Related: 칠월, 칠십(70).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: August 15th is Liberation Day.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Eight (8). Sino-Korean 八 but also means 'arm' (native). 8 is lucky number. Related: 팔월(August), 팔리다(to sell, homophone).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: You need to memorize the multiplication table.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Nine (9). Sino-Korean 九. 구구단(multiplication table, literally 9×9 table). Related: 구월(September), 구십(90).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Let's meet in ten minutes.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Ten (10). Sino-Korean 十. Combine logically: 십일(11), 이십(20), 이십삼(23). Related: 십분(fully), 십 년(10 years).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: This bag is 35,100 won.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Hundred (100). Sino-Korean 百. Say 백 not 일백 for 100. Related: 백일(100 days), 이백(200), 삼백(300).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: The bus fare is 1,300 won.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Thousand (1,000). Sino-Korean 千. Say 천 not 일천 for 1,000. Related: 천 원(1,000 won), 이천(2,000).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: These clothes are 50,000 won.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Ten thousand (10,000). Sino-Korean 萬. Korean groups by 만 not 1,000 like English. Trickiest for English speakers. Related: 오만(50,000).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Please give me just one.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: One (native Korean). Shortens to 한 before counters: 한 개(one item), 한 명(one person). Related: 하나가 아니다(it's not just one).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Let's go together, just the two of us.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Two (native Korean). Shortens to 두 before counters: 두 개, 두 명. 둘이(two people together). Related: 둘다(both).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Choose one out of three.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Three (native Korean). Shortens to 세 before counters: 세 개, 세 명. Used when counting standalone. Related: 셋 중(among the three).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: We need four chairs.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Four (native Korean). Shortens to 네 before counters: 네 개, 네 명. 네 sounds like 'your' (possessive) causing sound shifts. Related: 네 개.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: There are five fingers.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Five (native Korean). Does NOT shorten: 다섯 개, 다섯 명. Related: 다섯 손가락(five fingers).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Let's meet at six o'clock.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Six (native Korean). Does NOT shorten. Hours use native: 여섯 시(6 o'clock). Related: 여섯 살(6 years old).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: One week is seven days.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Seven (native Korean). Native numbers rarely used beyond 99. Used for days: 일곱 일(7 days). Related: 일주일(one week).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: I go to work at eight o'clock.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Eight (native Korean). Hours: 여덟 시(8 o'clock). Pronounced '여덜' casually; ㅂ often silent. Related: 여덟 시에 출근해요(I go to work at 8).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: You have to come by nine o'clock.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Nine (native Korean). 아홉 시까지(by 9 o'clock). 까지(by/until) is common time marker. Related: 아홉 살(9 years old).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: I practiced ten times.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Ten (native Korean). Combines with units: 열하나(11), 열둘(12). 열 번(ten times). Related: 열 명(10 people).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: I'm twenty years old this year.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Twenty (native Korean). Shortens to 스무 before counters: 스무 살(20 years old). Irregular form. Related: 스무 명(20 people).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example: 서른 살이 되면 뭘 하고 싶어요?
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: What do you want to do when you turn thirty?
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Thirty (native Korean). Used mainly for age. Sino-Korean 삼십 preferred for other contexts. Related: 서른 살(30 years old).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: My father is forty-five years old.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Forty (native Korean). Mostly for age: 마흔다섯 살(45 years old). In daily life, Sino-Korean 사십 more common. Related: 마흔 살.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: My grandmother started exercising from age fifty.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Fifty (native Korean). Used mainly for age. Beyond 50, native numbers rare except for age counting. Related: 쉰 살(50 years old).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Please give me three apples.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Counter for general items/things. Most common versatile counter. Use when unsure. Related: 사과 세 개(three apples), 한 개(one item).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: The four of us eat together.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Counter for people (polite). Related: 두 명(two people), 네 명(four people). Honorific version: 분(two people, respectful).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Do you want to drink a cup of coffee?
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Counter for cups/glasses. Common: 커피 한 잔(one cup of coffee). 한잔하다 colloquially means 'to have a drink (alcohol).'

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: I raise two cats.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Counter for animals. Used for all animals regardless of size. Related: 고양이 두 마리(two cats), 개 한 마리(one dog).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Please lend me a sheet of paper.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Counter for flat things (paper, tickets, photos). Related: 종이 한 장(one sheet of paper), 사진 한 장(one photo).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example: 이번 달에 책 세 권을 읽었어요.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: I read three books this month.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Counter for books. Used for bound volumes: books, notebooks, magazines. Related: 책 세 권(three books), 잡지 한 권(one magazine).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: I bought a bottle of water.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Counter for bottles. Also means 'illness/disease' (different meaning). Context makes it clear. Related: 물 한 병(one bottle of water).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: There are two cars.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Counter for vehicles/machines. Used for cars, computers, phones, TVs. Related: 차 두 대(two cars), 휴대폰 한 대(one phone).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: I bought a new set of clothes.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Counter for sets of clothing. Counts outfits or suits: 한 벌(one outfit). Not for individual items. Related: 옷 한 벌(one suit).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: How old are you?
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Counter for age (years old). Use with native numbers: 한 살(1 year old), 두 살(2 years old). 몇 살(how old?). Related: 살다(to live).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Try one more time.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Counter for times/occurrences. 한 번(once), 두 번(twice). Also for route numbers: 버스 삼번(bus #3). Related: 번 더(one more time).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Get off at the third floor.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Counter for floors/stories. Uses Sino-Korean: 일 층(1st floor), 이 층(2nd floor). 지하 일 층(basement 1). Related: 지하(basement).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: I have a ten-thousand won bill.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Korean won (currency). Always uses Sino-Korean numbers. Common bills: 천 원, 오천 원, 만 원. Related: 돈(money), 가격(price).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: My grandmother is sixty years old this year.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Sixty (native Korean). Mainly for age: 예순 살(60 years old). Related: 할머니 예순 살(grandmother is 60).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Seventy people live in this village.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Seventy (native Korean). Less common in daily speech than 칠십. Mainly for age. Related: 일흔 명(70 people).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: My grandfather is over eighty.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Eighty (native Korean). Mostly for age: 여든 살(80 years old). Related: 할아버지 여든(grandfather is 80).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: It's the ninety-ninth attempt.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Ninety (native Korean). Highest tens digit in native system. 아흔아홉(99). Related: 아흔 명(90 people).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: First, health is the most important thing.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: First/firstly. Can mean 'first child' (birth order). Related: 둘째(second), 셋째(third). Common: 첫째, 건강이 제일 중요(first, health matters most).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: The second child starts school this year.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Second/secondly. Can mean 'second child.' Used to list points in order. Related: 첫째(first), 셋째(third).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: We finally arrived on the third day.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Third/thirdly. Used for ordinal listing or birth order. Related: 첫째(first), 넷째(fourth). 셋째 날(third day).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Please sit in the fourth row.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Fourth/fourthly. Follows native Korean ordinal pattern. Related: 다섯째(fifth). 넷째 줄(fourth row).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Please cut the apple in half.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Half. Also used in time: 두 시 반(2:30). Related: 반이(not quite), 반으로 자르다(cut in half).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Shall we meet around three o'clock?
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: About/approximately. Particle attached to numbers/time casually. Related: 세 시쯤(around 3 o'clock). Casual approximation.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: We need more than ten people to gather.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: More than/above. Includes the stated number: 열 명 이상(10 or more). Related: 이하(less than or below).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Children twelve and under are free.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Less than/below. Includes the stated number: 열두 살 이하(12 or fewer). Related: 이상(more than).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: It takes about ten minutes from here.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Approximately/about. Placed before number, more formal than 쯤. Related: 약 십 분(about 10 minutes).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example: 오늘 비 올 확률이 팔십 퍼센트예요.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: The chance of rain today is eighty percent.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Percent. Loanword from English. Used with Sino-Korean: 팔십 퍼센트(80%). Related: 확률(probability), 비율(ratio).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example: 이 가방은 저것보다 두 배 비싸요.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: This bag is twice as expensive as that one.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Times/fold (multiples). Used for 배: 두 배(twice/double), 세 배(three times). Related: 배로(by fold), 배수(multiple).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Half of the work is done.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Half (noun, formal). More formal than 반. Used as standalone noun: 일의 절반(half of the work). Related: 반(half).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: What time do we leave?
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: How many/some. Question word. Also means 'a few': 몇 번(a few times). Related: 몇 시(what time?). Essential question word.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Is everyone ready?
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: All/everyone. Can refer to people (everyone) or things (all of them). Related: 모두가(all of us), 모두 함께(all together).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: How much is all of this?
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Everything/all of it. Emphasizes totality. 전부 다(absolutely everything) is redundant but common. Related: 전부 이에요(that's all).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: I'll do the rest tomorrow.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: The rest/remainder. From 남다(to remain). Used for leftover portions. Related: 나머지 사람들(the rest of the people).

가족 (Family).example_en: My family has four members.
가족 (Family).notes: From 家族: 가(家 house) + 족(族 family/group). Related: 가정(family/household), 가족사진(family photo).

가족 (Family).example_en: My parents live in Busan.
가족 (Family).notes: From 父母: 부(父 father) + 모(母 mother). 님 is honorific. Say 우리 부모님(our parents) not 내 부모님.

가족 (Family).example_en: Dad made dinner for us.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Casual/affectionate. Formal: 아버지. Most respectful: 아버님. Common: 아빠가 앞장서다(Dad leads the way).

가족 (Family).example_en: Mom, what are you doing today?
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Casual/affectionate. Formal: 어머니. Most respectful: 어머님. Conjugation: 엄마가/엄마를/엄마와.

가족 (Family).example_en: My older brother goes to university.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Only males address older brother. Also used for older male friends. Related: 형님(respectful), 형이뭐하세요?(What's your brother doing?).

가족 (Family).example_en: My older sister is good at cooking.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Only males address older sister. Also: older female friend. Related: 누나가(by my sister). Female equivalent: 언니.

가족 (Family).example_en: Oppa, let's go watch a movie together.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Only females address older brother or older male friend. Common phrase: 오빠 뭐해?(What's oppa doing?). Similar: 형(for males).

가족 (Family).example_en: My older sister bought me new clothes.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Only females address older sister or older female friend. Related: 오빠(opposite for males). Common: 언니한테(to sister).

가족 (Family).example_en: My younger brother is a high school student.
가족 (Family).notes: From 男: 남(male) + 동생(younger sibling). Related: 여동생(younger sister), 막내(youngest). Conjugation: 남동생이/남동생을.

가족 (Family).example_en: My younger sister is cute.
가족 (Family).notes: From 女: 여(female) + 동생(younger sibling). Related: 남동생(younger brother), 친동생(blood sibling). Conjugation: 여동생이/여동생과.

가족 (Family).example_en: Grandfather told us a story.
가족 (Family).notes: From 父: 할(father/grandfather) + 아버지(father). Also used to address any elderly man respectfully. Related: 할머니(grandmother).

가족 (Family).example_en: I go to grandmother's house often.
가족 (Family).notes: From 母: 할(mother/grandmother) + 어머니(mother). Affectionate and respectful. Related: 할아버지(grandfather). Honorific: 할머님.

가족 (Family).example_en: My son starts elementary school this year.
가족 (Family).notes: From 男: 아(male) + 들(suffix). Related: 딸(daughter), 첫아들(eldest son), 아들딸(children). Common: 아들 같다(like a son).

가족 (Family).example_en: My daughter sings really well.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Related: 아들(son), 맏딸(eldest daughter), 외동딸(only daughter). Common phrase: 딸내미(affectionate for daughter).

가족 (Family).example_en: My husband cooks for me.
가족 (Family).notes: From 男 and 便: 남(male) + 편(side/person). Formal. Casual: 남자 or address by name. In speech: Often just 신랑(groom) or 남편.

가족 (Family).example_en: I'm going on a trip with my wife.
가족 (Family).notes: From 女: 아(female) + 내(wife). Formal. Related: 부인(wife, also means 'lady'). In speech: Often called 아내씨 or just 아들의 엄마(mom of the child).

가족 (Family).example_en: The child is playing in the park.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Covers children and kids. Related: 아기(baby), 어린아이(small child). Plural: 아이들(children). Common: 아이를 돌보다(take care of a child).

가족 (Family).example_en: The baby is sleeping right now.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Specifically infants/toddlers. Related: 아이(child), 신생아(newborn), 갓난아기(newborn). Diminutive: 아기자기(cute, like a baby).

가족 (Family).example_en: I bought a birthday present for my niece/nephew.
가족 (Family).notes: From 甥: 조(niece/nephew) + 카(suffix). Covers nieces and nephews. Related: 조카딸(niece), 조카아들(nephew). Common: 조카들(nieces and nephews).

가족 (Family).example_en: My uncle lives in Seoul.
가족 (Family).notes: From 叔: 삼(uncle father's side) + 촌(relation). Unmarried father's brother. Related: 큰아버지(father's elder brother), 아주버니(father's younger brother).

가족 (Family).example: 이모가 맛있는 음식을 많이 해 주세요.
가족 (Family).example_en: My maternal aunt makes a lot of delicious food.
가족 (Family).notes: From 母: 이(mother's side) + 모(mother). Mother's sister. Related: 외할머니(maternal grandmother), 이모부(aunt's husband). Common: 이모댁(aunt's house).

가족 (Family).example_en: My paternal aunt lives in America.
가족 (Family).notes: From 姑: 고(father's sister) + 모(mother). Father's sister. Related: 고모부(aunt's husband). Hierarchical: 큰고모(father's elder sister), 작은고모(younger).

가족 (Family).example_en: My cousin is getting married next week.
가족 (Family).notes: From 四 and 村: 사(four) + 촌(relations). Covers all cousins. Etymology: Cousin is 4 degrees of relation. Related: 사촌형(older cousin male), 사촌누나(older cousin female).

가족 (Family).example_en: My mother-in-law made kimchi for us.
가족 (Family).notes: From 媤 and 母: 시(husband's family) + 어머니(mother). Mother-in-law (husband's mother). Related: 시아버지(father-in-law), 시집가다(marry and go to husband's family).

가족 (Family).example_en: My mother-in-law (wife's mom) came to visit.
가족 (Family).notes: From 丈: 장(wife's family) + 모(mother) + 님(honorific). Wife's mother. Formal/respectful. Related: 장인어른(wife's father), 사위(son-in-law).

가족 (Family).example_en: My maternal grandfather lives in the countryside.
가족 (Family).notes: From 外 and 父: 외(outside/mother's side) + 할아버지(grandfather). Maternal grandfather. Related: 외할머니(maternal grandmother), 할아버지(paternal grandfather).

가족 (Family).example_en: My maternal grandmother sent us kimchi.
가족 (Family).notes: From 外 and 母: 외(mother's side) + 할머니(grandmother). Maternal grandmother. Related: 외할아버지(maternal grandfather), 외갓집(maternal grandparents' house).

가족 (Family).example_en: How many brothers/siblings do you have?
가족 (Family).notes: From 兄 and 弟: 형(older brother) + 제(younger brother). Often means siblings in general. Related: 자매(sisters), 형제자매(brothers and sisters).

가족 (Family).example_en: I have two sisters.
가족 (Family).notes: From 姉 and 妹: 자(older sister) + 매(younger sister). Refers to female siblings only. Related: 형제(brothers/siblings), 형제자매(all siblings).

가족 (Family).example_en: My sister-in-law (brother's wife) cooks really well.
가족 (Family).notes: From 兄 and 媤: 형(older brother) + 수(wife). Used by older brother's wife reference. Only used by males. Related: 올케(sister-in-law female perspective).

가족 (Family).example_en: My sister-in-law is coming to visit next week.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean (onomatopoeia). Sister-in-law (brother's wife). Used by females. Related: 형수(male perspective), 사위(son-in-law). Common: 올케와 친하다(close with sister-in-law).

가족 (Family).example_en: My brother-in-law drove me to the airport.
가족 (Family).notes: From 昧 and 兄: 매(sister's husband) + 형(older brother/man). Used by males for sister's husband. Related: 형(older brother), 처남(wife's brother).

가족 (Family).example_en: My wife's brother came back from the military.
가족 (Family).notes: From 妻 and 男: 처(wife's) + 남(male/brother). Wife's brother. Related: 처제(wife's sister), 시누이(brother's wife). Used in: 처남댁(brother-in-law's house).

가족 (Family).example_en: My father-in-law's birthday is today.
가족 (Family).notes: From 媤 and 父: 시(husband's family) + 아버지(father). Father-in-law (husband's father). Related: 시어머니(mother-in-law), 시댁(husband's family).

가족 (Family).example_en: I was nervous meeting my father-in-law for the first time.
가족 (Family).notes: From 丈: 장(wife's family) + 인(person). Wife's father. Formal: 장인어른. Related: 장모님(wife's mother), 사위(son-in-law). Respectful address: 장인어른.

가족 (Family).example_en: My daughter-in-law is very kind.
가족 (Family).notes: From 媳: 며(daughter-in-law) + 느(emphasis) + 리(person). Son's wife. An important role traditionally. Related: 사위(son-in-law), 시어머니(mother-in-law).

가족 (Family).example_en: Our son-in-law is a doctor.
가족 (Family).notes: From 壻: 사(son-in-law). Daughter's husband. Related: 며느리(daughter-in-law), 장인(wife's father). Traditional: 사윗감(potential son-in-law candidate).

가족 (Family).example_en: My grandson starts school this year.
가족 (Family).notes: From 孫 and 子: 손(grandchild) + 자(male). Male grandchild. Related: 손녀(granddaughter), 손주(all grandchildren). Common: 손자들(grandsons).

가족 (Family).example_en: My granddaughter sings really well.
가족 (Family).notes: From 孫 and 女: 손(grandchild) + 녀(female). Female grandchild. Related: 손자(grandson), 손주(all grandchildren). Affectionate: 손녀가여(like a granddaughter).

가족 (Family).example_en: My friend has a twin brother.
가족 (Family).notes: From 雙: 쌍(pair/double) + 둥(pair) + 이(person). Twins. Related: 일란성(identical), 이란성(fraternal). Common: 쌍둥이 형제(twin brothers), 쌍둥이 자매(twin sisters).

가족 (Family).example_en: I'm an only child so I don't have siblings.
가족 (Family).notes: From 外 and 獨: 외(alone) + 동(alone). Only child. Related: 외동딸(only daughter), 외동아들(only son). Modern: 외동이 많아졌어요(More only children now).

가족 (Family).example_en: The youngest is the cutest.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Youngest family member. Related: 맏이(eldest), 첫째(first-born). Honorific: 막내님. Common: 막내같이 행동하다(act like the youngest).

가족 (Family).example_en: I have a strong sense of responsibility because I'm the eldest.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Eldest family member. Related: 막내(youngest), 첫째(first-born). Common: 맏아들(eldest son), 맏딸(eldest daughter). In groups: 조직의 맏이(organization leader).

가족 (Family).example_en: In the past, extended families lived together.
가족 (Family).notes: From 大 and 家族: 대(big/great) + 가족(family). Extended family. Becoming rarer in modern Korea. Related: 핵가족(nuclear family). Common: 대가족 가정(large family household).

가족 (Family).example_en: These days nuclear families are common.
가족 (Family).notes: From 核 and 家族: 핵(nuclear/core) + 가족(family). Parents + children only. The modern standard. Related: 대가족(extended family). Modern Korean society: Most are 핵가족 now.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Have you eaten? (Did you eat rice?)
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 飯: 밥(cooked rice). 밥 먹었어요? is the most common greeting. Related: 쌀(uncooked rice), 밥그릇(rice bowl), 밥 먹다(eat a meal).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I eat bread in the morning.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From Portuguese 'pão.' Loanword. Korea has vibrant bakery culture (빵집). Related: 식빵(sliced bread), 단팥빵(sweet bean bread), 크림빵(cream bread).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Cold noodles are delicious in summer.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 國 and 粹: 국(noodle dish) + 수(thread). General noodle term. Related: 우동(thick noodles), 국수를 삶다(cook noodles). Common: 잔치국수(banquet noodles).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We grill the meat and eat it.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 肉: 고(meat) + 기(quality). General meat term. Related: 고깃집(meat restaurant), 고기 구우다(grill meat). Korean BBQ is cultural center of dining.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Korean beef (hanwoo) is expensive.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 牛 and 肉: 소(cow) + 고기(meat). Beef. Related: 한우(Korean beef, premium), 쇠고기(older term). Common: 소고기국(beef broth).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Samgyeopsal is pork.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 豬: 돼지(pig) + 고기(meat). Pork. Most consumed meat in Korea. Related: 삼겹살(pork belly, premium cut), 돈까스(pork cutlet/tonkatsu).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We make fried chicken with chicken meat.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 鷄: 닭(chicken animal) + 고기(meat). Chicken meat. Note: ㄺ cluster (닭). Related: 치킨(fried chicken), 닭다리(chicken leg).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Do you like fish?
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 生 and 鮮: 생(fresh) + 선(fish). Fish as food. Related: 물고기(fish animal), 생선구이(grilled fish), 회(sashimi). Contrast: 물고기(living fish).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Eating lots of vegetables is good for health.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 菜 and 蔬: 채(vegetable) + 소(plant). Standard term for vegetables. Related: 야채(older/casual term), 채소를 다지다(chop vegetables).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I eat fruit after meals.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 果 and 實: 과(fruit) + 일(thing/fruit). General fruit term. Related: 딸기(strawberry), 포도(grapes), 과일 시장(fruit market).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: One apple is 1,000 won.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 沙 and 果: 사과(apple fruit). Also means 'apology' completely different word! Related: 홍로(Red Delicious variety), 사과잼(apple jam). Homonym: 사과하다(apologize).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I eat a banana in the morning.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From English 'banana.' Loanword. Korea imports most bananas. Related: 바나나우유(banana milk, iconic drink), 바나나 같다(curved like banana).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: The strawberries are really sweet.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 多 and 粒: 딸(many) + 기(grains). Strawberry. Korean strawberries (딸기) famous for size and sweetness. Related: 딸기잼(strawberry jam), 딸기 따다(pick strawberries).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We eat a lot of watermelon in summer.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 水 and 瓠: 수(water) + 박(gourd). Watermelon. Quintessential summer fruit in Korea. Related: 수박 서리(stealing watermelons from field, playful), 수박겉핥기(superficial knowledge).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: The grapes look delicious.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 葡 and 萄: 포(grapes) + 도(grapes). Korean grapes (캠벨 포도) often darker, sweeter. Related: 포도주(wine/grape alcohol), 포도나무(grapevine).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I can't eat a meal without kimchi.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Korea's most iconic food; UNESCO recognized. Related: 배추김치(napa cabbage kimchi most common), 김치 담그다(make kimchi). Essential in every meal.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Please make soybean paste stew.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 豉 and 醬: 된장(soybean paste made from beans-豆) + 찌개(stew). Staple comfort food. Related: 김치찌개(kimchi stew), 찌개를 끓이다(make stew).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example: 소풍 갈 때 김밥을 싸 가요.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We pack kimbap when we go on picnics.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 海 and 苔: 김(seaweed/nori) + 밥(rice). Korean rice roll, looks like sushi but different. Related: 계란말이(egg roll), 김밥을 말다(roll kimbap).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I put red pepper paste in bibimbap.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 非 and 飯: 비빔(mixing) + 밥(rice). Mix everything with sauce. UNESCO recognized. Related: 돌솥비빔밥(hot stone bibimbap), 비비다(to mix).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Bulgogi is sweet and delicious.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 火 and 肉: 불(fire) + 고기(meat). Thin-sliced beef marinated in sweet sauce, grilled. Related: 소불고기(beef bulgogi), 불고기 양념(bulgogi marinade).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I bought tteokbokki in front of the school and ate it.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 糕 and 炒: 떡(rice cake) + 볶이(stir-fried). Most popular Korean street food. Related: 떡(rice cake), 국떡(soup rice cakes), 떡볶이 소스(tteokbokki sauce).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Let's go eat samgyeopsal for dinner tonight.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 三 and 層: 삼(three) + 겹(layers) + 살(meat). Pork belly (3 layers of fat/meat). Grilled at table. Related: 소삼겹(beef belly), 돼지삼겹살(pork belly).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Ramyeon comes to mind on rainy days.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From Japanese 'ramen.' Loanword. Korean ramyeon spicier than Japanese. Related: 신라면(Shin Ramyun brand), 라면을 끓이다(cook ramyeon), 라면값(ramyeon price index).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I often eat cold noodles in summer.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 冷 and 麵: 냉(cold) + 면(noodles). Cold noodles. Related: 물냉면(in chilled broth), 비빔냉면(spicy mixed cold noodles), 냉면 국물(cold broth).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We marinate the ribs in sauce and grill them.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 肋: 갈(ribs). Can be beef (소갈비) or pork (돼지갈비). Related: 양념갈비(marinated ribs), 갈비탕(rib soup), 갈비를 구우다(grill ribs).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Beer goes well with fried chicken.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From English 'chicken.' Loanword. Korean fried chicken cultural phenomenon. Related: 치맥(fried chicken + beer), 황금찰떡 치킨(golden crispy chicken), 순살치킨(boneless chicken).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We make dumplings on Lunar New Year.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 滿 and 頭: 만(full) + 두(head). Dumplings. Related: 찐만두(steamed dumplings), 군만두(fried dumplings), 만두국(dumpling soup), 만두를 빚다(make dumplings).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We eat rice cake on holidays.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 糕: 떡(rice cake). Made from pounded rice. Hundreds of varieties. Related: 떡국(rice cake soup, eaten on New Year's), 흰떡(white rice cake), 떡 썬다(slice rice cakes).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I fry an egg and eat it.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Eggs. Related: 계란(another common word for egg, from 鷄 and 卵), 달걀을 삶다(boil eggs), 계란말이(egg roll/omelette).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I like soft tofu stew.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 豆 and 腐: 두(bean) + 부(curdled). Tofu staple in Korean cooking. Related: 순두부(soft/silken tofu), 두부를 끓이다(cook tofu), 두부 같다(soft like tofu, mild personality).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I wash the rice and cook it.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 粒: 쌀(rice grain). Uncooked rice. Related: 밥(cooked rice), 쌀밥(white rice meal), 쌀값(rice price), 현미(brown rice).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Please put in just a little salt.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 鹵: 소(salt) + 금(metal/precious). Essential seasoning. Related: 소금기(saltiness), 천일염(sea salt), 소금을 뿌리다(sprinkle salt). Used in superstitions: 소금을 뿌리다(ward off evil).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Do you put sugar in your coffee?
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 雪: 설(snow) + 탕(soup/liquid). Sugar (white like snow). Related: 설탕이 많이 들어있다(has lots of sugar), 올리고당(oligosaccharide), 단 맛(sweet taste).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I dip it in soy sauce and eat it.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 肝 and 醬: 간(fermentation) + 장(sauce/paste). Foundational seasoning made from soybeans. Related: 국간장(soup soy sauce), 진간장(thick soy sauce), 간장 양념(soy sauce marinade).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I put red pepper paste in bibimbap.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 椒 and 醬: 고추(red pepper) + 장(paste). Essential condiment. Sweet, spicy, fermented. Related: 된장(soybean paste), 고추장을 풀다(dilute gochujang with water).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I make stew with soybean paste.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 豉 and 醬: 된(fermented) + 장(paste). Soybean paste (fermented). One of Korea's 3 essential seasonings. Related: 된장찌개(soybean soup), 된장을 풀다(dilute paste).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Adding sesame oil to namul makes it delicious.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 眞 and 油: 참(true/real/sesame) + 기름(oil). Sesame oil. Nutty aroma essential to Korean cooking. Related: 들기름(perilla oil), 참기름 향(sesame aroma).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Please give me a glass of water.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Water. In Korean restaurants water is almost always free (unlike soft drinks). Related: 물을 마시다(drink water), 물의약(water as medicine).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I drink milk in the morning.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 牛 and 乳: 우(cow) + 유(milk). Milk. Related: 바나나우유(banana milk), 딸기우유(strawberry milk), 흰우유(plain milk), 우유팩(milk carton).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I'd like to drink orange juice.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From English 'juice.' Loanword. Korea has many unique juices. Related: 오렌지주스(orange juice), 포도주스(grape juice), 100% 주스(100% juice).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example: 한국 사람들은 커피를 정말 많이 마셔요.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Korean people drink a lot of coffee.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From Portuguese 'café' via English 'coffee.' Loanword. Korea has highest coffee consumption rates. Related: 아메리카노(americano), 카페(café), 커피 한 잔(a cup of coffee).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I like green tea.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 茶: 차(tea). Includes all types. Related: 녹차(green tea), 보리차(barley tea), 옥수수차(corn tea), 차를 마시다(drink tea).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I want to have a glass of beer.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 麥 and 酒: 맥(barley) + 주(alcohol). Beer. Korean beer brands include Cass, OB, Hite. Related: 맥주를 마시다(drink beer), 소주와 맥주(soju and beer mixed).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example: 소주는 한국에서 제일 인기 있는 술이에요.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Soju is the most popular alcohol in Korea.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 燒 and 酒: 소(distilled) + 주(alcohol). Korea's national spirit. Clear, 16-20% ABV. Related: 소주잔(small soju glass), 소주 한 잔(one shot), 소주폭탄(soju bomb, mixed with beer).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Cola goes well with fried chicken.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From English 'cola.' Loanword. Related: 펩시(Pepsi), 사이다(Sprite/7-Up in Korea), 무카페인(caffeine-free cola). Korean: Often called 검은콜라(black cola).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Let's go eat ice cream.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From English 'ice cream.' Loanword. Korea has unique flavors. Related: 딸기아이스크림(strawberry ice cream), 밀크쉐이크(milkshake), 빙수(shaved ice dessert).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We eat cake on birthdays.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From English 'cake.' Loanword. Korean cakes lighter, less sweet than Western. Related: 초콜릿 케이크(chocolate cake), 생일 케이크(birthday cake), 케이크를 자르다(cut the cake).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example: 과자를 너무 많이 먹으면 안 돼요.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: You shouldn't eat too many snacks.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 果 and 子: 과(fruit) + 자(small). General term for packaged snacks/cookies. Related: 초콜렛(chocolate), 칩(chips), 새우깡(prawn-flavored crackers), 과자를 먹다(eat snacks).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I boil potatoes and eat them.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Potato. 감자탕(pork bone and potato stew) is popular. Related: 감자튀김(french fries), 감자를 삶다(boil potatoes), 감자칩(potato chips).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Please chop the carrot finely.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From English 'carrot' or Portuguese 'cenoura.' Loanword. Also slang for 당연하지(of course!) — used as '당근!'(of course!). Related: 당근과 무(carrots and radish).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: When you cut onions, tears come out.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 洋: 양(Western) + 파(onion). Literally 'Western onion.' Related: 파(native Korean onion/scallion), 양파를 자르다(chop onions), 양파 향(onion smell/aroma).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Korean food uses a lot of garlic.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Garlic. Korea is world's top garlic consumer. Related: 마늘쫑(garlic greens), 마늘을 까다(peel garlic), 마늘향(garlic aroma), 까마늘(black garlic).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: The chili pepper is too spicy!
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 椒: 고(chili) + 추(pepper). Chili pepper. Related: 고춧가루(chili powder/flakes essential for gochujang), 청고추(green chili), 고추를 자르다(chop peppers).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We wrap samgyeopsal in lettuce and eat it.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Lettuce. 쌈(wrapping food in leaves) key Korean eating custom. Related: 상추 쌈(lettuce wrap), 상추에 싸서 먹다(eat wrapped in lettuce), 적상추(red leaf lettuce).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I slice cucumbers thinly and make a salad.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Cucumber. 오이소박이(stuffed cucumber kimchi) popular summer side. Related: 오이 지게장(cucumber in soy sauce), 오이를 잘게 자르다(dice cucumbers), 오이냉국(chilled cucumber soup).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I eat tomatoes sprinkled with sugar.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From Latin 'tomato,' via Spanish. Loanword. In Korea eaten as fruit with salt/sugar. Related: 방울토마토(cherry tomatoes), 토마토 주스(tomato juice), 토마토를 자르다(slice tomatoes).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We make kimchi with napa cabbage.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Napa cabbage. Main ingredient in kimchi (most common type). Related: 배추를 절이다(salt napa cabbage), 배추김치(napa cabbage kimchi), 배추 가격(napa cabbage price).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Adding mushrooms makes the broth delicious.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Mushroom. Common varieties: 표고버섯(shiitake), 팽이버섯(enoki), 느타리버섯(oyster), 송이(pine mushroom). Related: 버섯을 볶다(sauté mushrooms), 버섯 향(mushroom aroma).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Korean chopsticks are metal.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 著 and 籤: 젓(to stick/pick) + 가락(stick). Chopsticks. Korean chopsticks uniquely flat, metal (vs. wooden/round in other countries). Related: 젓가락질(chopstick technique), 젓가락으로 집다(pick up with chopsticks).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: You eat soup with a spoon.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Spoon. In Korea rice eaten with spoon (not chopsticks). Related: 숟가락으로 떠서 먹다(eat with a spoon), 밥 먹을 때 숟가락 쓰다(use spoon to eat rice).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example: 남은 밥으로 볶음밥을 만들어요. 간단하고 맛있어요.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I make fried rice with leftover rice. It's simple and delicious.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 炒 and 飯: 볶음(stir-frying) + 밥(rice). Fried rice. Popular way to use leftover rice. Related: 볶다(to stir-fry), 중국볶음밥(Chinese fried rice), 김볶음밥(seaweed fried rice).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We always make japchae on holidays.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 雜 and 菜: 잡(mixed) + 채(vegetables). Stir-fried glass noodles beloved Korean dish. Related: 고추장 잡채(spicy version), 검은 깨(black sesame), 잡채 양념(japchae sauce).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: On cold days, soft tofu stew is the best.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 順 and 豆: 순두부(soft/silken tofu) + 찌개(stew). Soft tofu stew. Usually served bubbling hot. Related: 두부찌개(regular tofu stew), 순두부 스크램블(scrambled silken tofu).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Pork goes well with kimchi stew.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 海: 김치(kimchi) + 찌개(stew). One of most common home-cooked Korean meals. Related: 된장찌개(soybean paste stew), 부찌(shortened version, spicy).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: If you eat ginseng chicken soup in summer, you get energized.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 參 and 鷄: 삼(ginseng) + 계(chicken) + 탕(soup). Ginseng chicken soup traditionally eaten in summer for stamina. Related: 삼(ginseng), 계(chicken), 탕(broth).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: The seafood at this restaurant is really fresh.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 海 and 物: 해(sea) + 물(thing). Seafood. Related: 해물탕(seafood stew), 해물파전(seafood pancakes), 해물을 끓이다(cook seafood).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I like fried shrimp. It's crispy.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Shrimp/prawn. 새우튀김(fried shrimp) popular side. 새우깡(shrimp-flavored crackers) iconic Korean snack. Related: 새우를 까다(peel shrimp), 새우 두마리(two shrimp).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Stir-fried squid is spicy and delicious.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Squid. Very popular in Korean cuisine. 오징어볶음(stir-fried squid) common side. Related: 오징어 무침(dressed squid), 오징어 다리(squid tentacle), 오징어를 살짝 익히다(lightly cook squid).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We dug for clams at the beach. It was fun.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Clam/shellfish. General term. 조개구이(grilled shellfish) popular. Related: 조개국(clam broth), 조개 칼국수(clam kalguksu), 조개류(shellfish in general).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Tuna kimbap is my favorite kimbap.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 參 and 魚: 참(true) + 치(fish). Tuna. 참치캔(canned tuna) pantry staple. Related: 참치 김밥(tuna kimbap), 참치회(tuna sashimi), 캔(canned fish).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Salmon sashimi is very popular these days.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 燕: 연(swallow/red) + 어(fish). Salmon. Extremely popular in modern Korea. 연어회(salmon sashimi) considered premium. Related: 연어 초밥(salmon sushi), 연어스테이크(salmon steak).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Peaches are sweet and delicious in summer.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Peach. Korean peaches large, juicy, very sweet. Related: 복숭아잼(peach jam), 복숭아 색(peach color), 복숭아를 깎다(peel a peach).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example: 한국 배는 크고 시원해요. 갈비 양념에도 넣어요.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Korean pears are big and refreshing. You put them in galbi marinade too.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Pear (Asian pear). Korean pears round, crisp, unlike Western elongated pears. Related: 배 주스(pear juice), 배를 깎다(peel a pear), 한 개 배(one pear).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: In winter, we eat tangerines under the blanket.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 橘: 귤(tangerine/mandarin). 제주도 귤(Jeju tangerines) famous. Eating tangerines on TV traditional. Related: 귤을 까다(peel a tangerine), 귤 향(tangerine aroma).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I put lemon in water and drink it. It's refreshing.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From English 'lemon.' Loanword. 레몬차(lemon tea), 레몬에이드(lemonade) popular drinks. Related: 레몬 슬라이스(lemon slice), 레몬 청(lemon extract preserve), 새콤한 맛(sour taste).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example: 망고 빙수가 여름에 정말 인기 있어요.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Mango bingsu is really popular in summer.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From Portuguese 'mango' via English. Loanword. Imported fruit popular in Korea. 망고빙수(mango shaved ice) summer dessert. Related: 망고 스무디(mango smoothie), 망고 주스(mango juice).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Cabbage is good for digestion. I eat it often.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 洋: 양(Western) + 배추(cabbage). Green cabbage (different from 배추 napa cabbage). Related: 배추(napa cabbage used for kimchi), 양배추 샐러드(cabbage salad).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Seasoned spinach is often eaten as a side dish.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 波 and 菜: 시금(greens) + 치(grass). Spinach. 시금치나물(seasoned spinach) one of most common Korean side dishes. Related: 나물(seasoned vegetable side), 시금치를 데치다(blanch spinach).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: In Korea, they make doenjang from soybeans.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Bean/soybean. Soybeans fundamental to Korean cuisine. Related: 두부(tofu from beans), 콩나물(bean sprouts), 콩을 심다(plant beans), 된장(soybean paste).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I eat nuts as a snack. They're good for your health.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 堅 and 果: 견(hard-shelled) + 과류(fruit category). Tree nuts. Includes 호두(walnut), 아몬드(almond), 땅콩(peanut), 캐슈너트(cashew). Related: 견과류 선물(nut gift set, traditional).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I mix honey in warm water and drink it.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Honey. Also slang for 'awesome' or 'the best.' Ex: 꿀 같아!(That's awesome!). Related: 꿀을 떠서(spoon out honey), 꿀물(honey water drink), 꿀 냄새(honey smell/sweetness).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example: 볶음 요리를 할 때 식용유가 필요해요.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: You need cooking oil when making stir-fried dishes.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 食 and 用: 식용(for eating) + 유(oil). Cooking oil general term. Related: 해바라기유(sunflower oil), 올리브유(olive oil), 기름을 두르다(pour oil in pan).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: If you add pepper to the soup, it's tastier.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From 胡 and 椒: 후(foreign) + 추(pepper). Black pepper. Note: Different from 고추(chili pepper). Related: 후춧가루(ground black pepper), 흰후추(white pepper).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I chop the green onion finely and put it in the soup.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Green onion/scallion. Essential Korean cooking ingredient. 대파(large scallion), 흰부분(white part), 초록부분(green part). Related: 파를 송송 썬다(slice green onions thinly).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: When I catch a cold, I drink ginger tea.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Ginger. Used in cooking, home remedies. 생강차(ginger tea) for colds. Related: 생강을 썬다(slice ginger), 생강 향(ginger aroma), 생강즙(ginger juice).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Is there a good restaurant near here?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Sino-Korean: 食(식, eat) + 堂(당, hall). Related words: 식당 경영 (restaurant management), 식당 메뉴 (menu). Collocation: 식당에 가다 (go to a restaurant).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: I'll take a look at the menu.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Loanword from English. Pronounced 메뉴 in Korean. Common phrases: 메뉴판 (menu board), 메뉴 추천 (menu recommendation).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Please give me the menu.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native compound: 메뉴 + 판 (board/plate). Related: 게시판 (bulletin board), 표지판 (sign). Often attached to tables or desks in Korean restaurants.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Please take our order.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Sino-Korean: 주(主, main) + 문(文, writing/order). Compound verb: 주문하다. Phrases: 주문이 들어왔어요 (order has come in), 주문을 받다 (take an order).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: I'll order. One bibimbap, please.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Grammar pattern: ~ㄹ게요 (intention/promise). Word family: 주문하다 → 주문할게요 (progressive), 주문했어요 (past). Essential dining phrase.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Excuse me! Can we get more water, please?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native Korean: 여기 (here) + 요 (polite). Contrast with 저기요 (for someone farther away). Cultural tip: raising your hand makes the call more effective in Korea.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Excuse me, water please.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Politeness particle: 좀 (a little/soften request) + 주세요 (please give). Free water refills are standard at Korean restaurants. Related: 음료 (beverage), 술 (alcohol).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example: 이거 주세요. 그리고 콜라도 하나 주세요.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: This, please. And one cola too, please.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native Korean: 이것 (this) + 거 (contraction). Word family: 이것, 이것 좀 (this a bit), 이거요 (Is this it?). Useful when you can't read Korean menu.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example: 여기 뭐가 맛있어요? 처음 와 봤어요.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: What's good here? It's my first time visiting.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native compound: 맛 (taste) + 있다 (exist) = tasty. Conjugation: 맛있다 → 맛있어요 (polite). Opens conversation and gets recommendations from staff.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: What's the recommended menu item?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Sino-Korean: 推(추, push) + 薦(천, recommend). Verb form: 추천하다 (to recommend). Phrase: 추천해 주세요 (please recommend), 이 음식 추천해요 (I recommend this dish).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example: 이거 매워요? 저는 매운 거 잘 못 먹어요.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Is this spicy? I can't handle spicy food well.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native adjective: 맵다 → 매워요 (irregular ㅂ consonant change). Related: 덜 맵게 (less spicy), 안 매워요 (not spicy). Essential for Korean dining—many dishes contain gochugaru (red chili).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example: 덜 맵게 해 주세요. 아이가 먹을 거예요.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Please make it less spicy. A child will be eating it.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Adverb structure: 덜 (less) + 맵게 (spicy manner). Alternatives: 안 맵게 (make it not spicy), 순한 맛 (mild flavor). Restaurants are accommodating to spice level requests.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Please eat a lot! (Enjoy your meal!)
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native Korean: 많다 (much) → 많이 (adverb). Honorific form: 드세요 (eat with respect). Cultural phrase: servers say '많이 드세요' as a warm farewell to diners.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example: 조금만 주세요. 배가 별로 안 고파요.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Just give me a little. I'm not that hungry.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native Korean: 조금 (a little) + 만 (only) = 조금만 (just a little). Casual form: 좀, 좀만. Useful for portion control or sampling multiple dishes.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Please give me more rice.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native Korean: 더 (more, additional). Common in dining: 반찬 더 (more side dishes), 물 더 (more water), 밥 더 (more rice). Refills are often free in Korean restaurants.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Can I get it to go?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Sino-Korean: 包(포, wrap) + 裝(장, package). Verb: 포장하다 (to package). Phrase: 포장해 주세요 (package it for me). Korea culture: taking leftovers home is completely normal and encouraged.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Please pack up the leftovers.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Request form of 포장하다. Usage: for takeout (going) or leftover (남은 거). Stylish trend: restaurants compete on eco-friendly containers and packaging.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: The check, please.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Sino-Korean: 計(계, calculate) + 算(산, math). Verb: 계산하다 (to calculate, pay). Cultural note: in Korea, you usually pay at the counter near exit, not at the table. Related: 계산대 (cashier counter).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Can I see the bill?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Sino-Korean: 계산(calculation) + 서(document). Suffix: 서 adds 'document' meaning. Related: 영수증 (receipt proof), 계산대 (payment counter). Used when itemized breakdown is needed.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: I'll pay by card.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Loanword from English. Full forms: 신용카드 (credit card), 체크카드 (debit card). Phrase: 카드 돼요? (Do you take card?). Card payment is ubiquitous in Korea—even street vendors accept cards.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: I'll pay in cash.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Sino-Korean: 現(현, present) + 金(금, money). Declining in use but necessary for small vendors. Phrase: 현금만 돼요 (cash only). Some places give discounts for cash payment due to card fees.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: I need a receipt.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Sino-Korean: 領(영, receive) + 收(수, receive) + 證(증, proof). Different from 계산서—this is the proof-of-payment receipt you get after paying. Required for refunds or returns.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: This kimchi stew is really delicious!
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native compound: 맛(taste) + 있다(to have/exist). Conjugation: 맛있다 → 맛있어요. Word family: 맛없다 (not tasty), 맛깔나다 (appetizing). Essential word—you'll use this constantly in Korea!

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: The food here is a bit not tasty.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native opposite pair: 맛있다 ↔ 맛없다. Conjugation: 맛없다 → 맛없어요. Tactful usage: be careful using directly to someone who cooked for you! Better to say 보통이에요 (it's okay) or find something specific to praise.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: This is too spicy! Water, please.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native adjective with irregular ㅂ consonant change: 맵다 → 매워요. Related: 순한맛 (mild), 중간맛 (medium), 매운맛 (spicy). Many Korean dishes default to spicy, so always check first!

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: This dessert is really sweet.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native adjective: 달다 → 달아요. Word family: 단맛 (sweetness), 달콤하다 (sweet/pleasant). Korean desserts like 호떡 (sweet pancake) and 붕어빵 (fish-shaped pastry) are popular; often paired with 약간 달다 (a bit sweet).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example: 국이 좀 짜요. 물 좀 넣어 주세요.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: The soup is a bit salty. Please add some water.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native adjective: 짜다 → 짜요. Compound noun: 짠맛 (salty taste). Caution: 짜다 also means 'stingy' in slang (짠머니 = stingy person). Request: 짜게 하지 말아 주세요 (please don't make it too salty).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: This coffee is a bit bitter.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native adjective: 쓰다 has multiple meanings: bitter (taste), to write (문을 쓰다), to use (돈을 쓰다). Context determines meaning. Conjugation: 쓰다 → 써요. Phrase: 쓴맛 (bitter taste).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example: 이 김치 좀 셔요. 오래된 거예요?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: This kimchi is a bit sour. Is it old?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native adjective: 시다 → 셔요. Word family: 신맛 (sour taste), 식초 (vinegar). Cultural note: well-fermented 김치 is supposed to be slightly sour (신 맛); it's often used for 김치찌개 (kimchi stew). Fresh kimchi tastes less sour.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: I ate too much so I'm stuffed.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native compound: 배(stomach) + 부르다(to be full). Irregular: 배부르다 → 배불러요 (ㄹ irregular). Antonym: 배고프다 (hungry). Phrase: 배부르게 먹었어요 (ate until full).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: They say the wait is thirty minutes.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Sino-Korean: 待(대, wait) + 機(기, machine/timing). Verb: 대기하다 (to wait). Phrases: 대기 명단 (wait list), 대기 번호 (waiting number). Common at popular restaurants, especially on weekends.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Are there any seats available?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native Korean: 자리 (seat, place, spot). Related words: 자리 잡다 (take a seat), 좋은 자리 (good spot). Used for restaurant tables, car seats, theater seats. Phrase: 창가 자리 (window seat), 안쪽 자리 (inside seat).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: I'd like to sit at a window seat.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native compound: 창가(by window) + 자리(seat). 창(window) + 가(side). Collocation: 창가 카페 (window-side cafe), 창가 좌석 (window seat). Popular request at restaurants and cafes in Korea.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Non-smoking section, please.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Sino-Korean: 禁(금, forbid) + 煙(연, smoke) + 席(석, seat). Opposite: 흡연석 (smoking section). Cultural note: most Korean restaurants and cafes are now fully non-smoking indoors. Request: 금연석이 있어요? (Do you have non-smoking?)

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: There are ten of us, do you have group seating?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Sino-Korean: 團(단, group) + 體(체, body) + 席(석, seat). Often implies a separate room (방) in Korean restaurants. Phrase: 단체 예약 (group reservation), 단체 할인 (group discount).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: I want to go to a buffet today.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Loanword from French 'buffet.' Pronounced 뷔페 in Korean. Related: 뷔페식 (buffet-style), 한정식 뷔페 (Korean set meal buffet). Growing trend in Korea for family dining.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: I'll order the course meal.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Loanword: 코스(course) + 요리(cooking/dish). Composed of multiple courses: 전채(appetizer), 스프(soup), 메인(main), 디저트(dessert). Common in Korean fine dining (한정식) and upscale restaurants.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: The set menu is cheaper.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Loanword: 세트(set) + 메뉴(menu). Typically includes main dish, rice/side, soup, and drink bundled at a discount. Budget-friendly option, very popular at Korean restaurants. Phrase: 세트로 할 거예요 (I'll take the set).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: The side dishes are really diverse.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native Korean: 반(half/side) + 찬(food/dish). Usually offered free and refillable. Common 반찬: 김(seaweed), 나물(vegetables), 계란말이(rolled egg), 버터 옥수수(buttered corn). Hallmark of Korean dining culture.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Can I get a water refill, please?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Loanword from English 'refill.' Phrases: 반찬 리필 (side dish refill, usually free), 음료 리필 (drink refill, sometimes charged). Koreans appreciate generous refills; it's considered good service.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: One more bowl of rice, please.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native compound: 공기(rice bowl) + 밥(rice/meal). Usually costs a small extra charge (1,000-2,000 won). Usage: when you run out of rice to eat with your main dish. Phrase: 밥 더 (more rice, informal).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: What beverages do you have?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Sino-Korean: 飮(음, drink) + 料(료, ingredient/material). Formal word; includes alcoholic and non-alcoholic. Casual alternatives: 마실 것 (something to drink), 음식 (food). Phrase: 음료수 (soft drink).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Dessert comes after the meal.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Loanword from French 'dessert.' Korean desserts often include 떡(rice cake), 과일(fruit), or 아이스크림(ice cream). Trend: 마카롱, 크로아상(croissants) are becoming popular. Phrase: 식후 디저트 (after-meal dessert).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: This is on the house.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Loanword from English 'service.' In Korean, 서비스 means 'free/bonus item given to customer.' Usage: 서비스 닭강정 (complimentary fried chicken), 음료 서비스 (free drink). Korean restaurants often surprise customers with free extras.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Please call the waiter.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Loanword from English 'waiter.' In Korea, people usually call out 여기요! or 저기요! instead of using 웨이터. Female form: 웨이트리스 (waitress). More common formal term: 종업원 (server).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: The head chef at this restaurant is famous.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Sino-Korean: 主(주, main) + 房(방, room) + 長(장, chief). Kitchen: 주방 (main cooking space). Loanword alternative: 셰프(chef). Phrase: 주방장의 특선 (chef's special), 주방장 추천 (chef's recommendation).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: In Korea, you don't need to leave a tip.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Loanword from English 'tip.' Cultural note: tipping is NOT customary in Korea and may even be refused politely. Prices include service charges; showing gratitude is appreciated but not expected as tip. Exception: sometimes 5-10% tips at high-end restaurants or spas.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Do you know a good restaurant around here?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native compound: 맛(taste) + 집(house/place). Casual word meaning 'a place known for delicious food.' Very popular in Korean culture—people love sharing 맛집 recommendations. Phrase: 맛집 블로거 (food blogger).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Sorry, can I cancel my order?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Compound: 주문(order) + 취소(cancellation). Verb phrase: 주문 취소하다 (to cancel an order). Sine-Korean: 取(취, take) + 消(소, erase). Be polite and timely—cancellations are harder after cooking has started.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: I have a peanut allergy.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Loanword: 알레르기(allergy) + 있어요(have). Phrase pattern: [food] 알레르기가 있어요. Common allergens: 땅콩(peanut), 우유(dairy), 계란(egg), 생선(fish). Important phrase for safety—restaurants are generally accommodating about allergens.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I don't have time. I need to go quickly.
