시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native Korean: 시(time) + 간(space/interval). Dual meaning: 'time' (abstract) and 'hour' (duration). Collocation: 시간이 없다 (no time), 두 시간 (two hours), 한 시간 (one hour).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: It's three o'clock now.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native Korean counter for hours. Use native Korean numbers: 한 시(1 o'clock), 두 시(2 o'clock), 세 시(3 o'clock), 네 시(4 o'clock)...아홉 시(9 o'clock), 열 시(10 o'clock), 열한 시(11 o'clock), 열두 시(12 o'clock).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Please wait just ten minutes.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Sino-Korean: 分(분, divide/minute). Use Sino-Korean numbers: 십 분(10 min), 이십 분(20 min), 삼십 분(30 min), 오십 분(50 min). Phrase: 분만 (just a few minutes), 몇 분 (how many minutes).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Please wait just thirty seconds.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Sino-Korean: 秒(초, second). Use Sino-Korean numbers like 분. Less commonly used in daily conversation than 분. Phrase: 30초만 (just 30 seconds), 한두 초 (a second or two).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I have class at 9 AM.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Sino-Korean: 午(오, noon) + 前(전, before) = before noon. Opposite: 오후 (PM). Formal time expressions use these. Phrase: 오전 10시(10 AM), 오전에 (in the morning/AM).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Let's meet at 2 PM.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Sino-Korean: 午(오, noon) + 後(후, after) = after noon. Paired with 오전. Phrase: 오후 3시(3 PM), 오후에 (in the afternoon/PM). Used for formal time expressions in business contexts.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: What do you do in the morning?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native Korean: 아침 (morning, dawn). Dual use: time period AND meal (breakfast). Related: 아침 식사(breakfast meal), 아침밥(breakfast rice). Greeting: 좋은 아침입니다(good morning, formal).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Do you want to eat lunch together?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Sino-Korean: 點(점, point/o'clock) + 心(심, center/middle) = midday/noon. Also means the lunch MEAL itself. Collocation: 점심시간(lunch time, usually 12-1 PM), 점심 먹었어요?(Did you eat lunch?).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Do you have time in the evening?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native Korean: 저녁 (evening, dusk). Dual meaning: time period AND dinner meal. Cultural greeting: 저녁 먹었어요?(Have you eaten dinner?) is a common way to greet someone. Phrase: 저녁 되었어요(evening has come).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Don't walk around alone at night.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native Korean: 밤 (night, darkness). Phrase: 밤새(all night long), 한밤중(middle of the night), 밤 먹는 음식(evening snack). Cultural note: Korea is generally very safe at night; 밤 문화(night culture) is vibrant with clubs, restaurants, PC방 open late.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Waking up at dawn is hard.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native Korean: 새벽 (early morning, before sunrise). Roughly 1 AM to sunrise. Cultural phrase: 새벽 배송(dawn delivery—a popular Korean e-commerce service that delivers very early). Related: 새벽 감시(dawn surveillance).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: The weather is nice today.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native Korean: 오늘 (today, this day). High-frequency word in daily conversation. Phrase: 오늘부터(starting from today), 오늘도(today too/again), 오늘은(as for today). Used constantly in Korean speech.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: What are you going to do tomorrow?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native Korean: 내일 (tomorrow, next day). Phrase: 내일 봐요(see you tomorrow—very common farewell), 내일도(tomorrow too), 내일은(as for tomorrow). Often used with future tense: ~할 거예요(will do).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: What did you do yesterday?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native Korean: 어제 (yesterday, previous day). Always used with PAST tense (unlike 내일). Phrase: 어제 저녁에(yesterday evening), 어제는(as for yesterday), 어제 봤어요(I saw it yesterday).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I have an exam the day after tomorrow.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native Korean: 모레 (day after tomorrow). Unique to Korean—English requires two words. Pairs with 그저께(day before yesterday). Phrase: 모레는(as for day after tomorrow), 모레부터(starting day after tomorrow).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I met a friend the day before yesterday.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native Korean: 그저께 (day before yesterday). Also written as 그제 (shorter form). Less common than 모레 but still widely used. Timeline: 그저께 → 어제 → 오늘 → 내일 → 모레.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Are you busy now?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native Korean: 지금 (now, this moment). Very high-frequency word. Phrase: 지금 당장(right now, immediately), 지금부터(starting now), 지금까지(until now). Conjugation hint: present tense ~해요 pairs well with 지금.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I'll call you later.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native Korean: 나중(later, future) + 에(at). Vague about timing—could mean minutes or hours later. Phrase: 나중에 봐요(see you later—very casual), 나중에야(only later/at last), 나중에라도(even if only later).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I have to wake up early tomorrow.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Adverb form of 일다 (to be early). Adjective: 일른 (early). Opposite: 늦게(late). Phrase: 일찍 자요(go to sleep early), 일찍 왔어요(came early), 일찍 일어나요(wake up early).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I went to sleep late yesterday.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Adverb form of 늦다 (to be late). Opposite: 일찍(early). Note distinction: 늦게 자요(sleep late) vs 늦었어요(I'm late/arrived late). Phrase: 늦게까지(until late), 늦은 밤(late night).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I always eat breakfast.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Sino-Korean: 恆(항, constant) + 常(상, always). Synonymous with 언제나, but more formal. Phrase: 항상 감사합니다(thank you always), 항상 건강하세요(always be healthy).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: What time do you usually wake up?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Sino-Korean: 普(보, common) + 通(통, through/general). Dual meaning: 'usually' (frequency) AND 'ordinary/normal' (adjective). Phrase: 보통 사람(ordinary person), 보통 정도(normal level).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I sometimes watch Korean movies.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native Korean: 가끔 (occasionally, sometimes). Frequency scale: 항상(always) > 보통(usually) > 가끔(sometimes) > 거의 안(almost never). Related: 가끔씩(every so often).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I have a meeting on Monday.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native element system: 월(moon/month). Five elements: 월(moon), 화(fire), 수(water), 목(wood), 금(gold), 토(earth), 일(sun). Phrase: 월요일마다(every Monday), 매주 월요일(every Monday).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I have Korean class on Tuesday.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native element: 화(火, fire). Part of traditional 오행(five elements system). Phrase: 화요일마다(every Tuesday), 화요일부터(starting Tuesday). Used in class schedules, work meetings.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I'm a bit busy on Wednesday.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native element: 수(水, water). Middle of the work week. Phrase: 수요일마다(every Wednesday), 매주 수요일(every Wednesday). In schools/offices, 수요일 often marks the midpoint of the week.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Do you have time on Thursday?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native element: 목(木, wood/tree). Approaching the weekend. Phrase: 목요일까지(by Thursday), 목요일부터(starting Thursday), 목요일 밤(Thursday night).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: It's Friday so I'm in a good mood!
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native element: 금(金, gold). Last work day. Slang: 불금(불타는 금요일 = 'burning Friday' = TGIF energy). Phrase: 금요일 밤(Friday night), 금요일 저녁(Friday evening).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: What are you going to do on Saturday?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native element: 토(土, earth). Part of 주말(weekend). Phrase: 토요일마다(every Saturday), 토요일 오전(Saturday morning), 토요일 밤(Saturday night). Common for social outings.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I usually rest on Sundays.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native element: 일(日, sun). Part of 주말(weekend). Cultural note: unlike some countries, many Korean shops and restaurants are OPEN on Sundays. Phrase: 일요일마다(every Sunday), 일요일 오후(Sunday afternoon).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Let's meet this Friday.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Structure: 이번(this time/current) + 주(week). Related pattern works for other time units: 이번 달(this month), 이번 해(this year), 이번 학기(this semester).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I'm going on a trip next week.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Structure: 다음(next) + 주(week). Related: 다음 달(next month), 다음에(next time), 다음주부터(starting next week). Pairs with future tense expressions.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I caught a cold last week.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Structure: 지난(last/past) + 주(week) = written as one word (unlike 이번 주). Related: 지난 달(last month), 지난 해(last year), 지난번(last time).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I exercise every day.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Structure: 매(every) + 일(day). Pattern extends: 매주(every week), 매달(every month), 매년(every year). Related: 매일매일(day after day), 매일 같이(every single day).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I play soccer every Saturday.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Structure: 매(every) + 주(week). Can combine with days: 매주 월요일(every Monday). Phrase: 매주 같은 시간에(every week at the same time).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I started learning Korean this year.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Structure: 올(this) + 해(year). Only used with 해 (year)—can't use 올 with other time units. Related: 올해도(this year too), 올해부터(starting this year).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I went to Korea last year.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Sino-Korean: 昨(작, previous) + 年(년, year). More common in speech than 지난해. Phrase: 작년 이맘때(this time last year), 작년 말(end of last year).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I want to go to Korea next year.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Sino-Korean: 來(내, coming) + 年(년, year). Phrase: 내년 봄에(next spring), 내년 여름(next summer), 내년부터(starting next year).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: When is your birthday?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native compound: 생(birth) + 일(day). Phrase: 생일 축하해요(Happy birthday!). Cultural tradition: Koreans celebrate with 미역국(seaweed soup) on birthdays—eating it symbolizes cleansing and renewal.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: What did you do on the weekend?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native compound: 주(week) + 말(end). One of the most common small-talk topics in Korea. Phrase: 주말은 어땠어요?(How was your weekend?), 즐거운 주말(happy weekend).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: What are you going to do for the new year?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native compound: 새(new) + 해(year). Greeting: 새해 복 많이 받으세요(Wishing you much luck in the new year—the standard New Year greeting). Phrase: 새해에는(for/in the new year).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: What do you do for Christmas?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Loanword from English 'Christmas.' Cultural note: Christmas is popular in Korea, especially for couples as a romantic holiday. Phrase: 메리 크리스마스(Merry Christmas), 크리스마스 선물(Christmas gift).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: The whole family gathers during holidays.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Sino-Korean: 名(명, name) + 節(절, festival/season). Major Korean holidays: 설날(Lunar New Year), 추석(Chuseok/Harvest Moon Festival). Phrase: 명절 연휴(holiday break), 귀성 대행(heading home for holidays).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Tomorrow is a day off.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Sino-Korean: 休(휴, rest) + 日(일, day). Types: 공휴일(public holiday), 연휴(consecutive days off), 휴가(vacation). Phrase: 휴일을 즐기세요(enjoy your day off).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I go to work on weekdays.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Sino-Korean: 平(평, ordinary) + 日(일, day). Opposite: 주말(weekend). Phrase: 평일 저녁(weekday evening), 평일은 바빠요(I'm busy on weekdays).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Mid-July is the hottest.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Sino-Korean: 中(중, middle) + 旬(순, ten-day period). Roughly days 11-20 of a month. Phrase: 이번 달 중순(mid-this month), 3월 중순에(in mid-March). Casual: just use 중 (7월 중에).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I'm busy at the end of December.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native Korean: 말 (end/tail). Related: 연말(end of year), 월말(end of month), 학기말(end of semester). Phrase: 이번 달 말에(at the end of this month), 12월 말(end of December).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Let's meet then.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native Korean: 그(that) + 때(time). Pairs with previously mentioned time. Phrase: 그때 뵈요(see you then), 그때부터(starting then), 그때는(as for that time).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I just arrived.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native Korean: 방금 (a moment ago, just now). Used with recent past events. Phrase: 방금 전에(just a moment ago), 방금 봤어요(just saw it), 방금 먹었어요(just ate).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I'll arrive soon.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native Korean: 곧 (very shortly, within minutes). Implies imminent action. Phrase: 곧 시작해요(starting very soon), 곧 오실 거예요(will be here very soon).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Did you wait long?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native Korean: 오래 (a long time, long duration). Phrase: 오래됐어요(been a long time), 오래 있어요(stays for a long time), 오래 봤어요(haven't seen you in a long time). Formal variant: 오랫동안.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Please wait just a moment.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native Korean: 잠시 (a short time, momentarily). More formal than 잠깐. Phrase: 잠시 후에(after a moment), 잠시만(just a moment/hold on), 잠시 동안(for a brief moment).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I studied for 3 hours.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native Korean: 동안 (duration/while). Used after time nouns. Phrase: 방학 동안(during vacation), 한 시간 동안(for one hour), 잠깐 동안(for a short while).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I went to Korea 2 years ago.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Sino-Korean: 前(전, before). Pattern: Time + 전에 = [time] ago. Phrase: 얼마 전(a while ago), 며칠 전(a few days ago), 하루 전(a day before).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Let's meet in 30 minutes.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Sino-Korean: 後(후, after). Pattern: Time + 후에 = after [time]. Phrase: 1시간 후(in 1 hour), 내일 후(tomorrow after), 수술 후(after surgery).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I get paid every month.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Structure: 매(every) + 달(month). Related: 매년(every year), 매주(every week), 매일(every day). Phrase: 매달 같은 날(same day every month).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I travel every year.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Structure: 매(every) + 년(year). Native Korean alternative: 해마다 (also means 'every year'). Phrase: 매년 이맘때(this time every year), 매년 반복(repeats every year).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: How many days does it take?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native Korean: 몇 일 (contraction = 며칠). Can be a question word or noun meaning 'several days.' Phrase: 며칠간(for several days), 며칠이나(as many as several days).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: How long does it take from here?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native Korean: 얼마나 (how much/how long). Used for both amount questions and duration questions. Phrase: 얼마나 오래(how long), 얼마나 자주(how often).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I studied Korean for half a year.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Native compound: 반(half) + 년(year) = 반년. More formal variant: 6개월(6 months). Phrase: 반년마다(every six months), 반년간(for six months).

장소 (Places).example_en: I want to go home.
장소 (Places).notes: Native Korean: 집 (house, home, dwelling). Particle distinction: 집에(to home, destination) vs 집에서(at home, location). Collocation: 집에 가다(go home), 집에서 쉬다(rest at home).

장소 (Places).example_en: How do you get to school?
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 學(학, study) + 校(교, school). Types: 초등학교(elementary), 중학교(middle school), 고등학교(high school), 대학교(university). Phrase: 학교에 다니다(attend school), 학교를 가다(go to school).

장소 (Places).example_en: I work at a company.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 會(회, meeting) + 社(사, company/organization). Related: 회사원(office worker/company employee), 회사 동료(coworker). Phrase: 회사에 다니다(work at a company), 회사 퇴근(leaving company).

장소 (Places).example_en: What floor is the office on?
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 事務(사무, business/work) + 室(실, room). Refers to physical office space. Related: 사무용(for office use), 사무 기기(office equipment). Phrase: 사무실 밖에서(outside the office).

장소 (Places).example_en: I'm sick so I need to go to the hospital.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 病(병, illness) + 院(원, institution). Broad category: includes hospitals and clinics. Cultural note: Koreans visit 병원 even for minor colds (antibiotics prescribed readily). Phrase: 병원에 가다(go to the hospital), 병원 진료(medical consultation).

장소 (Places).example_en: I bought medicine at the pharmacy.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 藥(약, medicine) + 國(국, bureau). Look for green cross sign (internationally recognized pharmacy symbol). Open late in many areas. Phrase: 약국에 가다(go to pharmacy), 약국 약사(pharmacist).

장소 (Places).example_en: I bought fruit at the mart.
장소 (Places).notes: Loanword abbreviation of 슈퍼마켓(supermarket). Major chains: 이마트, 홈플러스, 롯데마트, 코스트코. Phrase: 마트에서 쇼핑(shopping at mart), 마트 물품(mart products).

장소 (Places).example_en: I'll go buy water at the convenience store.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 便(편, convenience) + 宜(의, suitable). Major brands: CU, GS25, 세븐일레븐, 이마트24. Open 24 hours typically. Cultural: Korean 편의점 sell food, drinks, toiletries, even financial services.

장소 (Places).example_en: I need to go to the bank and send money.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 銀(은, silver) + 行(행, business/trade). Major Korean banks: 국민은행, 신한은행, 우리은행, 하나은행. Related: 은행 계좌(bank account), 은행 송금(bank transfer).

장소 (Places).example_en: I sent a package at the post office.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 郵(우, postal) + 遞(체, deliver) + 局(국, bureau). Less used now due to online services, but still common for domestic packages. Phrase: 우편(mail), 택배 발송(package sending).

장소 (Places).example_en: How long does it take to get to the airport?
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 空(공, air/empty) + 港(항, port/harbor). Korea's main international airport: 인천공항(Incheon). Domestic: 김포공항(Gimpo, Seoul). Phrase: 공항 픽업(airport pickup), 공항 버스(airport shuttle).

장소 (Places).example_en: Let's meet at Seoul Station.
장소 (Places).notes: Native Korean: 역 (station). Works for both train and subway. Pattern: [city/location] + 역. Examples: 강남역(Gangnam Station), 홍대역(Hongdae Station). Major stations often used as meeting points.

장소 (Places).example_en: Where is the bus stop?
장소 (Places).notes: Native compound: 버스(bus) + 정류장(stopping place). Alternative: 버스 정거장. Recognized by numbered signs. Phrase: 버스 정류장을 찾다(find a bus stop), 버스 번호(bus number).

장소 (Places).example_en: I like studying at cafes.
장소 (Places).notes: Loanword from English 'cafe.' Korea has massive cafe culture—millions of cafes everywhere. Cultural: many people study, meet friends, or work in 카페. Phrase: 카페에서 커피(coffee at cafe), 카페 문화(cafe culture).

장소 (Places).example_en: Have you been to that restaurant? They say it's good.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 食(식, eat) + 堂(당, hall/establishment). General term for any Korean eatery. Related: 한식당(Korean restaurant), 양식당(Western restaurant). Phrase: 식당 예약(restaurant reservation).

장소 (Places).example_en: I take walks in the park.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 公(공, public) + 園(원, garden). Famous parks: 한강공원(Han River Park), 서울숲(Seoul Forest). Phrase: 공원에서 놀다(play in park), 공원 산책(park walk).

장소 (Places).example_en: I borrowed a book from the library.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 圖書(도서, books) + 館(관, building). Related: 빌리다(to borrow), 반납하다(to return). Cultural: many Koreans study at libraries during exam seasons. Phrase: 도서관 이용증(library card).

장소 (Places).example_en: I saw a new movie at the theater.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 映畫(영화, movie) + 館(관, hall). Major Korean cinema chains: CGV, 메가박스, 롯데시네마. Phrase: 영화표(movie ticket), 영화 예매(movie reservation online).

장소 (Places).example_en: I bought a gift at the department store.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 百(백, hundred) + 貨(화, goods) + 點(점, store). Upscale shopping destination. Famous stores: 롯데백화점, 현대백화점, 신세계백화점. More formal/expensive than 마트.

장소 (Places).example_en: I ate tteokbokki at the market.
장소 (Places).notes: Native Korean: 시장 (marketplace, traditional market). Famous markets: 남대문시장(Namdaemun Market), 광장시장(Gwangjang Market). Great for street food and bargaining. Cultural experience for visitors.

장소 (Places).example_en: I went to the shopping mall on the weekend.
장소 (Places).notes: Loanword: 쇼핑(shopping) + 몰(mall). Large modern malls: 코엑스몰, 스타필드. Multiple floors with restaurants, cafes, shops. Phrase: 쇼핑몰 구경(mall browsing).

장소 (Places).example_en: Where is the restroom?
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 化妝(화장, makeup) + 室(실, room). Most polite way to ask. Public restrooms in Korea are usually clean and free. Phrase: 화장실 찾다(find a restroom), 화장실 위치(restroom location).

장소 (Places).example_en: I go to church every Sunday.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 教(교, teaching) + 會(회, gathering/assembly). Christianity is one of Korea's major religions (약 30%). Cultural: many Koreans attend church on Sundays. Phrase: 교회 목사(pastor).

장소 (Places).example_en: I visited a temple on the weekend.
장소 (Places).notes: Native Korean: 절 (Buddhist temple). Famous temples: 불국사(Bulguksa), 해인사(Haeinsa). Alternative: 사(寺, Sino-Korean). Cultural destination for tourists and hikers. Phrase: 절 구경(temple visit), 절 묵언(temple silence).

장소 (Places).example_en: Did you book a hotel?
장소 (Places).notes: Loanword from English 'hotel.' Budget alternatives in Korea: 모텔(motel), 게스트하우스(guesthouse), 한옥 스테이(Korean traditional house stay). Phrase: 호텔 예약(hotel reservation), 호텔 숙박(hotel stay).

장소 (Places).example_en: I live in an apartment.
장소 (Places).notes: Loanword from English 'apartment.' Most common housing type in Korea—about 60% of Koreans live in 아파트. Related: 아파트 단지(apartment complex), 아파트 분양(apartment sale). Phrase: 아파트 관리비(apartment maintenance fee).

장소 (Places).example_en: How many rooms are there?
장소 (Places).notes: Native Korean: 방 (room, space). Used in compounds: 노래방(karaoke room), PC방(internet cafe), 찜질방(spa/sauna), 게임방(gaming room). Related: 침실(bedroom), 안방(master bedroom).

장소 (Places).example_en: I'm cooking in the kitchen.
장소 (Places).notes: Native Korean: 부엌 (kitchen). Formal alternative: 주방 (more common in commercial/restaurant kitchens). Korean kitchens often have floor heating (온돌) like the rest of the home. Phrase: 부엌 일(kitchen chores).

장소 (Places).example_en: I watch TV in the living room.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 居(거, reside) + 實(실, room). The main shared space in Korean homes. Related: TV, sofa, 티테이블(tea table). Phrase: 거실 창문(living room window), 거실 소파(living room sofa).

장소 (Places).example_en: The bathroom is clean.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 浴(욕, bath) + 室(실, room). Refers to the bathing room/shower area. Distinction: 화장실 (toilet/restroom) vs 욕실 (bathing room). Korean bathrooms often have heated floors.

장소 (Places).example_en: I attend a cram school.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 學(학, study) + 院(원, institution). Private tutoring is extremely common in Korea—Korea has the highest 학원 density worldwide. Types: 영어 학원(English academy), 수학 학원(math academy).

장소 (Places).example_en: I majored in economics at university.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 大(대, big/great) + 學(학, study) + 校(교, school). Forms: 대학교 (formal) or 대학 (casual). Shortened: 대 (in speech, as in '어느 대 나왔어요?' = 'What university did you graduate from?').

장소 (Places).example_en: My child goes to kindergarten.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 幼(유, infant/young) + 稚(치, young) + 園(원, garden). For ages 3-5 typically. Precedes 초등학교(elementary school). Phrase: 유치원 입학(kindergarten admission), 유치원 선생님(kindergarten teacher).

장소 (Places).example_en: The kids are playing at the playground.
장소 (Places).notes: Native compound: 놀이(play) + 터(place/ground). Found in most 아파트 complexes. Slides, swings, see-saws common. Phrase: 놀이터에서 놀다(play at playground), 안전한 놀이터(safe playground).

장소 (Places).example_en: I go to the gym every day.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 體育(체육, physical education) + 館(관, hall). Colloquial: 헬스장(health club, from English 'health'). Equipment: 러닝머신(treadmill), 덤벨(dumbbells), 요가(yoga). Phrase: 체육관 회원(gym membership).

장소 (Places).example_en: I go to the swimming pool often in summer.
장소 (Places).notes: Native compound: 수영(swimming) + 장(place/facility). Many 아파트 complexes have their own pools. Phrase: 실내 수영장(indoor pool), 옥외 수영장(outdoor pool), 수영 강습(swimming lessons).

장소 (Places).example_en: I got a haircut at the hair salon.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 美(미, beauty) + 容(용, appearance) + 室(실, room). Male-only barbershops called 이발소(barber shop). Services: 펌(perm), 염색(dyeing), 매직(straightening). Phrase: 미용사(stylist), 미용 비용(salon cost).

장소 (Places).example_en: I left my coat at the dry cleaner.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 洗(세, wash) + 濯(탁, launder) + 所(소, place). Mostly used for DRY CLEANING in Korea (of formal wear, coats). Phrase: 세탁소 맡기다(drop off at dry cleaner), 세탁 비용(dry cleaning cost).

장소 (Places).example_en: I need to get gas at the gas station.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 注(주, pour) + 油(유, oil) + 所(소, place). Types: 셀프 주유소(self-service), 풀서비스 주유소(full-service). Phrase: 휘발유(gasoline), 경유(diesel), 기름을 넣다(fill up).

장소 (Places).example_en: I lost my wallet so I went to the police station.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 警(경, police) + 察(찰, inspect) + 署(서, office). Korean emergency: 112 (police), 119 (fire/ambulance). Related: 경찰관(police officer), 신고(report). Phrase: 신고하다(file a report).

장소 (Places).example_en: The fire station is near my house.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 消(소, extinguish) + 防(방, prevent) + 署(서, office). Korean emergency: 119 (for fire and ambulance). Related: 소방관(firefighter), 소방차(fire truck). Phrase: 119에 신고(call 119).

장소 (Places).example_en: I lost my passport so I need to go to the embassy.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 大(대, great) + 使(사, envoy) + 館(관, building). Most embassies in Seoul located in 용산 area. Services: visa, passport replacement. Related: 영사관(consulate).

장소 (Places).example_en: I want to go to the beach in summer.
장소 (Places).notes: Native compound: 해(sea) + 변(side/edge). Famous Korean beaches: 해운대(Busan), 경포대(Gangneung). Phrase: 해변 산책(beach walk), 해변 휴가(beach vacation), 해변 경기(beach sports).

장소 (Places).example_en: I went to the mountain on the weekend.
장소 (Places).notes: Native Korean: 산 (mountain). Hiking (등산) is Korea's national hobby—mountains are everywhere and well-maintained. Phrase: 산에 오르다(climb a mountain), 산책(walking/strolling), 산 정상(mountain peak).

장소 (Places).example_en: I like eating chicken by the Han River.
장소 (Places).notes: Native Korean: 강 (river, waterway). Famous Korean river: 한강(Han River) flowing through Seoul. Cultural: 치맥(fried chicken + beer) by the river is iconic Korean activity. Phrase: 강변 공원(riverside park).

장소 (Places).example_en: I want to go to a jjimjilbang and rest this weekend.
장소 (Places).notes: Native compound: 찜질(sweating/steaming bath) + 방(room). Uniquely Korean experience: large public bathhouse with multiple saunas, sleeping rooms, restaurants. Open 24 hours often. Very affordable and social.

장소 (Places).example_en: The parking lot is in the basement.
장소 (Places).notes: Native compound: 지(ground) + 하(below). Levels: 지하 1층(B1), 지하 2층(B2). Related: 지하철(subway—literally 'underground rail'). Phrase: 지하 주차장(underground parking lot).

장소 (Places).example_en: The night view from the rooftop is beautiful.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 屋(옥, roof) + 上(상, top). Many Korean buildings have accessible rooftops. Trends: 옥상 카페(rooftop cafe), 옥상 바비큐(rooftop BBQ). Cultural: romantic hangout spots in Korean cities.

장소 (Places).example_en: This restaurant's kitchen is very clean.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 主(주, main) + 房(방, room). More formal than native 부엌. Often used in commercial/restaurant contexts. Phrase: 주방장(head chef), 주방용품(kitchen supplies).

장소 (Places).example_en: I dry the laundry on the balcony.
장소 (Places).notes: Loanword from English 'veranda.' Common in Korean apartments—often enclosed and used for storage/laundry. Alternative: 발코니(from English 'balcony'). Phrase: 베란다 창문(balcony window).

장소 (Places).example_en: Don't run in the hallway.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 複(복, multiple) + 道(도, way). Used in buildings, schools, apartments, hospitals. Phrase: 복도 쪽(hallway side), 복도를 따라(along the hallway), 복도 밖(outside hallway).

장소 (Places).example_en: When it rains, I cross through the underground passage.
장소 (Places).notes: Native compound: 지하(underground) + 도(way/passage). Pedestrian underpass beneath a road—very common near busy intersections in Korean cities. Safe, convenient way to avoid traffic and weather.

장소 (Places).example_en: If you cross the overpass, you can see the school right away.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 陸(육, land) + 橋(교, bridge). Pedestrian bridge over a road. Many being replaced by 지하도 in modern cities. Phrase: 육교를 건너다(cross the overpass).

장소 (Places).example_en: There are many good restaurants in this alley.
장소 (Places).notes: Native Korean: 골목 (alley, narrow lane). Korean cities full of charming 골목 with hidden restaurants and shops. Phrase: 골목길(alley path), 골목을 돌다(turn down an alley), 골목 맛집(hidden alley restaurant).

장소 (Places).example_en: A festival is being held at Gwanghwamun Plaza.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 廣(광, wide/broad) + 場(장, place). Famous: 광화문 광장(Gwanghwamun Plaza) in Seoul—most famous public square in Korea. Phrase: 광장 집회(plaza gathering/rally).

장소 (Places).example_en: In summer, children play at the fountain.
장소 (Places).notes: Native compound: 분수(fountain) + 대(platform/stand). Many Korean parks have fountains where children play in summer. Phrase: 분수 쇼(fountain show), 분수대 주변(fountain area).

장소 (Places).example_en: There is a beautiful garden at my grandmother's house.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 庭(정, garden) + 園(원, garden). Refers to private or public gardens. Korean garden style distinctive: natural harmony, rocks, plants, water. Phrase: 한국 정원(Korean garden), 정원 설계(garden design).

장소 (Places).example_en: In Seoul, there are many apartments and few houses.
장소 (Places).notes: Sino-Korean: 住(주, dwell) + 宅(택, home). More formal than native 집. Types: 단독주택(detached house), 다가구주택(multi-family house), 연립주택(townhouse). Phrase: 주택 시장(housing market).

장소 (Places).example: 저 빌딩은 몇 층이에요? 정말 높아요.
장소 (Places).example_en: How many floors does that building have? It's really tall.
장소 (Places).notes: Loanword from English 'building.' Usually refers to tall commercial/office buildings. Residential buildings called 아파트 or 건물. Phrase: 사무실 빌딩(office building), 빌딩 층수(number of floors).

장소 (Places).example_en: I lived in a rooftop room when I was a college student.
장소 (Places).notes: Native compound: 옥(roof) + 탑(top) + 방(room). Often the cheapest housing option. Famous in Korean dramas as home of struggling protagonists. Has floors heating (온돌) but often exposed to elements. Phrase: 옥탑방 월세(rooftop room rent).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a bank on the left.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 왼 (left) + 쪽 (side/direction). Word family: 왼손 (left hand), 왼쪽으로 (to the left).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Go to the right.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 오른 (right) + 쪽 (side/direction). Word family: 오른손 (right hand), 오른쪽 먼저 (right side first).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Let's meet in front of the school.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Used with 에 or 에서 for location. Related: 앞으로 (forward/from now on), 앞뒤로 (back and forth).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a parking lot behind the building.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 뒤에 (behind in location) vs 뒤로 (backward direction). Related: 뒤에서 봤어요 (I saw it from behind).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a book on top of the desk.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Essential location word. Collocations: 위에 놓다 (place on top), 위에서 봤어요 (saw from above).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a bag under the chair.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 아래에 (below/under location). Related: 아래로 내려가다 (go down), 위아래 (up and down).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a cafe next to the post office.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 옆에 (next to location). Collocations: 바로 옆에 (right next to), 옆에 앉다 (sit beside).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: It's between the bank and the pharmacy.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: A 와/과 B 사이에 = between A and B. Also figurative: 사이가 좋다 (get along well), 사이 = relationship.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Please go inside the building.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 안에 (inside location), 안에서 (from inside). Opposite: 밖 (outside). Related: 안과 밖 (inside and outside).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: It's raining outside.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 밖에 (outside location), 밖에서 (from outside). Opposite: 안. Collocation: 밖으로 나가다 (to go outside).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Can I sit here?
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Part of proximity system: 여기 (near me) vs 거기 (near you) vs 저기 (far from both). Essential for navigation.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Please wait there.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Refers to a place near the listener or previously mentioned. Proximity word in 이/그/저 system.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: What's that building you can see over there?
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Refers to a place far from both speaker and listener. Often accompanied by pointing gesture.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Please come this way.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 이 (this) + 쪽 (direction). Very commonly used when guiding someone: 이쪽입니다 (this way, please).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: If you go that way, there's a station.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 그 (that) + 쪽 (direction). Also a polite way to refer to 'you' in formal contexts: 그쪽은 뭐 하세요?

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: The restroom is over that way.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 저 (that far) + 쪽 (direction). Used when pointing to somewhere distant from both speaker and listener.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: It's close from here.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Adverb form of 가깝다 (close). Irregular adjective: 가깝다 → 가까워요. Collocation: 가까이 오다 (come closer).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: My home is far from the office.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Adverb form of 멀다 (far). Irregular adjective: 멀다 → 멀어요. Opposite of 가깝다.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a mart across from the bank.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 건너 (to cross) + 편 (side). Interchangeable with 맞은편. Useful for giving directions across streets.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a cafe on the opposite side of the station.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 맞은 (facing) + 편 (side). Synonym of 건너편. Common in navigation and location descriptions.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Go straight on this road.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 직 = straight (Sino-Korean) + 진 = advance. Used in GPS navigation and giving directions: 직진 후 우회전.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Go right at the intersection.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: ~(으)로 가세요 is the standard pattern for giving directions. Polite imperative: 가세요, casual: 가.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Go left at the convenience store.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Same directional pattern as 오른쪽으로 가세요. Always use landmarks as reference points in directions.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Where is the restroom?
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Essential question pattern. Structure: [Subject 이/가] 어디에 있어요? Most asked phrase in directions.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Can I go this way?
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Also means 'way/path' figuratively. Collocations: 길을 잃다 (get lost), 길을 건너다 (cross the street).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Please show me the map.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 지 = land (Sino-Korean) + 도 = diagram. In Korea, 네이버 지도 and 카카오맵 are the dominant mapping apps.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: If you turn the corner, there's a cafe.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 모퉁이를 돌다 = turn a corner. Also called 코너 (English loanword). Used in navigation.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Go left at the intersection.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 사 = four (Sino-Korean) + 거리 = street/distance. Related: 삼거리 (three-way intersection), 신호등 (traffic light).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Cross at the crosswalk.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 횡 = cross (Sino-Korean) + 단 = section + 보도 = walkway. Casual: 건널목. Important for pedestrian safety.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Come out through exit 3.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 출 = exit (Sino-Korean) + 구 = opening. Subway stations have numbered exits. Great for giving meeting locations: 3번 출구 앞에서.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Seoul is in the northern part of Korea.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 북 = north (Sino-Korean). Compass directions: 북쪽 (north), 남쪽 (south), 동쪽 (east), 서쪽 (west).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Busan is in the south.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 남 = south (Sino-Korean). Related: 남한 (South Korea), 남북 (North and South).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: The sun rises in the east.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 동 = east (Sino-Korean). Related: 동해 (East Sea), 동京 (Seoul). Essential for cardinal directions.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: The sun sets in the west.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 서 = west (Sino-Korean). Related: 서해 (West Sea), 서울 (Seoul = 'capital of the west').

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a fountain in the center of the plaza.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 중 = middle (Sino-Korean) + 앙 = center. Related: 중앙선 (center line), 중앙 정부 (central government).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a cafe at the end of this street.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Also means 'finish/completion': 끝났어요 (it's over/finished). Opposite: 처음 (beginning).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: I'll explain again from the beginning.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 처음에 = at first (temporal). 처음이에요 = it's my first time. Opposite: 끝.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: The pharmacy is on the opposite side of the street.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 반대 = opposite + 쪽 = side. Very useful for giving directions: 길 반대쪽에 있어요.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Please go up the stairs.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 계 = steps (Sino-Korean) + 단 = level. Related: 계단을 내려가다 (go down stairs), 에스컬레이터 (escalator).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: The elevator is broken.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Loanword from English. Casual: 엘베. Common phrase: 엘리베이터를 탔어요 (I took the elevator).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Take the escalator to this floor.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Loanword from English. Very common in Korean malls and subway stations. Collocation: 에스컬레이터를 타다 (ride an escalator).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Is there a bank nearby?
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 근 = near (Sino-Korean) + 처 = place. Phrase: 근처에 있어요 (it's nearby). Common in asking for directions.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: The cafe is on the first floor.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Korean 1층 = ground floor (American system, not British). Related: 2층 (second floor), 지하 1층 (basement).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: We have to go around because of construction.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 돌다 (to turn) + 아가다 (to go). Also means 'to pass away' (honorific: 돌아가시다). Conjugation: 돌아가요, 돌아갔어요.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: If you pass the bank, you'll see the school.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 지나다 (to pass) + 가다 (to go). Also: 시간이 지나가다 (time passes). Conjugation: 지나가요, 지나갔어요.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Just follow this road.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 따르다 (to follow) + 가다 (to go). Very useful for giving directions. Conjugation: 따라가요, 따라갔어요.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Please cross at the crosswalk.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 건너다 (to cross) + 가다 (to go). Related phrase: 길을 건너가다 (to cross the street). Conjugation: 건너가요.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Turn right at the next corner.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 돌다 = to turn/rotate. Related: 왼쪽으로 돌다 (turn left), 한 바퀴 돌다 (go around once). Conjugation: 돌아요, 돌았어요.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Please place it horizontally.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 가로 = width/horizontal direction. Related: 가로등 (street lamp), 세로 (vertical). Opposite: 세로.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Please stand it up vertically.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 세로 = height/vertical direction. Opposite of 가로 (horizontal). Used when describing orientation of objects.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: This store is really good.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: General word for small shops. More casual than 상점 (store). Related: 편의점 (convenience store), 카페 (cafe).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: There are a lot of items.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Refers to physical goods/merchandise. Different from 것 (thing, more abstract). Collocation: 물건을 사다 (buy things).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Let's go buy a gift.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: ~(으)러 가다 = 'to go in order to.' Conjugation: 사요 (present), 샀어요 (past). Essential shopping verb.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: What do they sell here?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 팔다 → 팔아요. ㄹ irregular: ㄹ drops before ㄴ, ㅂ, ㅅ endings. Related: 팔아요 (sell), 팔리다 (to be sold).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: The price is a bit expensive.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 가 = price (Sino-Korean) + 격 = level. More formal than asking 얼마예요? Collocation: 가격을 깎다 (negotiate price).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: How much is this?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: The most essential shopping phrase. Works everywhere: markets, stores, restaurants. Point at the item when asking.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: It's too expensive. Please give me a discount.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 비싸다 → 비싸요. Conjugation: 비싸요 (present), 비쌌어요 (past). Bargaining is common at traditional markets, not at fixed-price stores.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: This place is really cheap!
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 싸다 → 싸요. Also means 'to wrap' in different context. Collocation: 싸게 사다 (buy cheaply). Opposite: 비싸다.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Is it on discount?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 할 = reduce (Sino-Korean) + 인 = reduce. Related: 할인하다 (to discount), 할인 카드 (discount card), 할인 행사 (sale event).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Is there a sale now?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Loanword from English 'sale.' Used interchangeably with 할인 in casual speech. Phrase: 세일 기간 (sale period).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: I'd like to exchange the size.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: General word for 'change/exchange/switch.' Conjugation: 바꿔요 (present), 바꿨어요 (past). Also means to replace.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Can I get a refund?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 환 = return (Sino-Korean) + 불 = pay. Related: 환불받다 (to receive a refund). Always keep receipt for refunds.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Is an exchange possible?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 교 = exchange + 환 = swap (both Sino-Korean). More formal than 바꾸다. Used for official store exchanges.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Do you have a different size?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Loanword from English. Korean sizes differ from Western sizes. 프리사이즈 = free size (one size fits all). Essential for clothing shopping.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example: 이거 좀 커요. 작은 거 있어요?
쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: This is a bit big. Do you have a small one?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 크다 → 커요. Used for both size and scale. Modifier form: 큰 (big adjective before nouns). Related: 크기 (size).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: This one is too small.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 작다 → 작아요. Conjugation: 작아요 (present), 작았어요 (past). Modifier form: 작은 (small adjective before nouns).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Do you have other colors?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Also shortened to 색. Common question: 무슨 색깔을 좋아해요? (What color do you like?) Used in shopping for clothes and accessories.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Please give me the red one.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 빨간 (red) + 색 (color). Base adjective: 빨갛다 (to be red). Related colors: 주황색 (orange), 분홍색 (pink).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: The blue one is prettier.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 파란 (blue) + 색 (color). Base adjective: 파랗다 (to be blue). Related: 남색 (navy blue), 연파랑 (light blue).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Do you have black pants?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 검은 (black) + 색. Also called 까만색 (deep/pure black) in casual speech. Base adjective: 까맣다 (to be black).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: The white one looks the cleanest.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 하얀 (white) + 색. Also 흰색. Base adjective: 하얗다 (to be white). Related: 회색 (gray), 베이지색 (beige).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: I'll pay by card. Here you go.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: ~(으)로 할게요 = 'I'll do it by/with.' Very common at checkout counters. Related: 현금으로 할게요 (I'll pay cash).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: I'll pay cash. Do you have change?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 현금 = cash money. 거스름돈 = change (money returned). Some shops offer small discounts for cash payment.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Do you need a bag?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Plastic bags cost money in Korea (usually 50-100 won). Environmentally conscious: bring your own bag to save money.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Receipt, please. I need to submit it to my company.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Some stores ask 영수증 필요하세요? (Do you need a receipt?) at checkout. Keep for tax deductions or returns.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Can I try on this dress?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: ~아/어 봐도 돼요? = 'may I try ~ing?' 입다 = wear (clothes), 신다 = wear (shoes). Essential shopping question.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Excuse me, how much is this?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Point at the item while asking. In markets, items may not have price tags. Very common in street shopping.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example: 좀 깎아 주세요. 두 개 살게요.
쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Please give a discount. I'll buy two.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 깎다 = cut/shave off. Only use at traditional markets, NOT at chain stores or fixed-price shops.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example: 마음에 안 들어요. 다른 거 있어요?
쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: I don't like it. Do you have something else?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 다른 = different/other. Collocation: 마음에 들다 (to like - literally: to enter one's heart). Very polite way to ask.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: I bought new shoes.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Related: 신다 (to wear shoes, different verb from 입다). Cultural note: Remove shoes when entering Korean homes and temples.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: There are a lot of pretty clothes.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: General term for clothing. Related: 옷가게 (clothing store), 옷을 입다 (to wear clothes). Collocation: 옷을 사다 (buy clothes).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: These pants are comfortable.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Covers all types: 청바지 (jeans), 반바지 (shorts), 레깅스 (leggings). Always plural in meaning. Related: 바지를 입다 (wear pants).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: The skirt is too short.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Related types: 미니 치마 (mini skirt), 긴 치마 (long skirt). 짧다 = to be short. Collocation: 치마를 입다 (wear a skirt).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: You look cooler when you wear a hat.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 모자를 쓰다 = wear a hat. Note: 쓰다 is the verb for hats/glasses, not 입다. Related: 야구 모자 (baseball cap).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: The bag is heavy.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: General term for any bag: backpack, purse, briefcase. Related: 책가방 (school bag), 핸드백 (handbag). Collocation: 가방을 메다 (carry a bag).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: These days I do a lot of online shopping.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 온라인 = online (Sino-Korean + loanword). Korea is one of the world's biggest online shopping markets.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: How long does delivery take?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 배 = distribute + 송 = send (Sino-Korean). Related: 당일 배송 (same-day delivery), 무료 배송 (free shipping).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: It's free shipping for orders over 30,000 won.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 무료 = free of charge (Sino-Korean). A major factor in Korean online shopping decisions. Common: 3만원 이상 무료 배송.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: The package arrived.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 택 = entrust + 배 = deliver (Sino-Korean). Related: 택배 기사 (delivery driver). Collocation: 택배를 받다 (receive a package).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: I ordered it online.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Works for both restaurant and shopping orders. Conjugation: 주문해요 (present), 주문했어요 (past). Related: 주문이 들어왔어요 (an order came in).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: I put it in the shopping cart.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 장 = market + 바구니 = basket. Used for both physical supermarket carts and online shopping carts. Collocation: 장바구니에 담다 (put in cart).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: I'll pay by card.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 결제하다 = pay/settle (Sino-Korean). Related: 결제 완료 (payment complete), 결제 수단 (payment method).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Can I pay by credit card?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 신용 = credit/trust (Sino-Korean). Korea has very high credit card usage. Related: 체크카드 (debit card).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: You need to have a balance for a debit card.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Loanword 'check' + Korean 카드. Draws directly from bank account. Popular among younger Koreans.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: I'll collect the points.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Loanword from English. 적립 = accumulate. Many Korean stores have point/reward systems: 포인트로 사다 (buy with points).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: If you have a coupon, you get a discount.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Loanword from English 'coupon.' Mobile coupons (모바일 쿠폰) are very common in Korea. Apps like Coupang offer coupons.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: The size doesn't fit so I'd like to exchange it.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 교환 = exchange (Sino-Korean). Different from 환불 (refund). Conjugation: 교환해요 (present), 교환했어요 (past).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Returns are possible within seven days.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 반 = return + 품 = goods (Sino-Korean). 반품하다 = to return an item. Important for online shopping within return periods.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: This is a defective item. Please exchange it.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 불량 = defective + 품 = product (Sino-Korean). Grounds for a full refund or exchange. Consumer protection is strong in Korea.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: It sold out quickly because it was popular.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 품 = goods + 절 = cut off (Sino-Korean). 품절되다 = to become sold out. Common in pop culture merchandise and trendy items.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: New arrivals came out today.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 신 = new + 상품 = product (Sino-Korean). Also called 신상 in casual speech. Related: 신상 공개 (new product reveal).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: It's much cheaper if you buy it secondhand.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 중 = mid + 고 = old (Sino-Korean). 중고품 = used item. Popular resale platforms: 당근마켓, 오늘의집, 쿠팡.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: What brand do you like?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Loanword from English 'brand.' 명품 브랜드 = luxury brand, 국산 브랜드 = Korean domestic brand.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: These pants don't fit.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Useful phrase when shopping for clothes. 큰 사이즈 = bigger size, 작은 사이즈 = smaller size. Common phrase: 사이즈를 바꾸고 싶어요.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Do you have this T-shirt in other colors?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Common question while shopping. Similar: 다른 디자인 있어요? (other designs?). Also: 다른 사이즈 있어요? (other sizes?).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The weather is really nice today.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: Used in everyday conversation. 기후 = climate (for long-term weather patterns). Collocation: 날씨가 좋다/나쁘다 (weather is good/bad).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: It's too hot in summer.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 덥다 = for weather/temperature. Different verb for hot food/drinks: 뜨겁다. Conjugation: 더워요 (present), 더웠어요 (past).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: It's really cold outside today.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 춥다 = for weather/body feeling. For cold objects/drinks, use 차갑다. Conjugation: 추워요 (present), 추웠어요 (past).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: When spring comes, the weather is warm.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: Can describe weather, clothing, personality, or food temperature. Conjugation: 따뜻해요. Collocation: 따뜻한 말 (warm words).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The breeze is refreshing.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 시원하다 = 'cool' for weather or 'refreshing' for cold drinks/breezes. Conjugation: 시원해요. Opposite: 덥다.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: It's raining a lot, so I need an umbrella.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 비 = the noun 'rain.' To say 'it rains,' use 비가 오다 (rain comes). 비를 맞다 = to get rained on.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: It will rain tomorrow.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: Korean literally says 'rain comes' rather than 'it rains.' Subject marker 가 attaches to 비. Conjugation: 와요, 왔어요.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The first snow has fallen!
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 눈 means both 'snow' and 'eye' - context makes it clear. 첫눈 = first snow of the season. Cultural: snow in Korea is special!

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: It snows a lot in winter.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: Same pattern as 비가 오다 (rain comes). Alternative: 눈이 내리다 (snow falls - more literary). Conjugation: 와요, 왔어요.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The wind is blowing hard today.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 바람 also means 'wish/hope' or 'affair' in other contexts. 세다 = strong (describes wind). Related: 바람이 불다 (wind blows).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: A cool breeze is blowing on the mountain.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 불다 = to blow. Also used for blowing out candles: 촛불을 불다. Collocation: 강한 바람이 불어요 (strong wind blows).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The sky is clear so I feel good.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 맑다 = for clear sky or clear water. For sunny weather: 맑은 날씨 is common. Conjugation: 맑아요 (present), 맑았어요 (past).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The sky is cloudy today.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 흐리다 can also mean 'blurry' or 'dim' when talking about vision/images. Conjugation: 흐려요 (present), 흐렸어요 (past).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: There are many clouds so the sun isn't visible.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 구름이 끼다 = clouds gather/it gets cloudy. Related: 구름이 걷히다 (clouds clear), 흰 구름 (white clouds).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: There was a lot of fog this morning.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 안개가 끼다 = fog sets in. Collocation: 안개 속에서 운전하다 (drive in fog). Related: 황사 (yellow dust), 스모그.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: A typhoon is coming, so we need to be careful.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 태 = great + 풍 = wind (Sino-Korean). Korea experiences typhoons mainly in late summer/early fall. Also called 허리케인 in English.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: I didn't bring an umbrella so I got rained on.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 비를 맞다 = get hit by rain. Related: 접이식 우산 (folding umbrella), 우산을 쓰다 (carry an umbrella).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: During the rainy season, it rains every day.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 장마철 = the rainy season period, usually late June to mid-July in Korea. Also called 보슬비 season. Everyone talks about this in early summer!

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: In spring, many flowers bloom.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 봄 = March to May in Korea. 벚꽃 (cherry blossoms) are the symbol of spring. Cultural: Cherry blossom festivals are major events.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: I want to go to the sea in summer.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: Korean summer: June to August, hot and humid, especially during 장마. Related: 여름방학 (summer vacation), 수박 (watermelon).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: In autumn, the fall foliage is really beautiful.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 단풍 = autumn leaves/fall colors (Sino-Korean). 가을 = September to November. Cultural: Autumn is considered most beautiful season in Korea.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: In winter, you have to wear warm clothes.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: December to February. Korean winters are very cold and dry. Related: 눈이 와요 (it snows), 스키장 (ski resort).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: Today the temperature is 30 degrees.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 온 = warmth + 도 = degree (Sino-Korean). Korea uses Celsius (섭씨). 영하 = below zero: 영하 5도 = minus 5 degrees Celsius.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: It's too humid in summer.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 습도 = humidity (Sino-Korean). Korea's summer humidity can feel oppressive, especially during 장마. Conjugation: 습해요, 습했어요.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: In winter, the air is dry.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 건조하다 used for weather, skin, or food. 피부가 건조하다 = skin is dry. Related: 촉촉하다 (moist). Conjugation: 건조해요, 건조했어요.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The fine dust is bad, so I wear a mask.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 미세 = fine + 먼지 = dust (Sino-Korean). Major concern in Korea, especially in spring. Check 미세먼지 forecasts on weather apps daily.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The weather forecast said it will be clear tomorrow.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 일기 = weather + 예보 = forecast (Sino-Korean). 일기 ≠ 일기장 (diary - different meaning). Check weather forecast apps before outings.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: When the sun rises, the weather gets warm.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 해 also means 'year' in other contexts. Related: 해가 뜨다 (sun rises), 해가 지다 (sun sets). Cultural: sunrise viewing (일출).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The moon is really bright tonight.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 달 also means 'month.' Related: 보름달 (full moon), 반달 (half moon). Cultural: 한가위 (Korean harvest festival) celebrates the full moon.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: You can see many stars in the countryside.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 별 can also mean 'star' as in celebrity. Related: 별똥별 (shooting star), 유명한 별 (famous celebrity/star).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: A sudden rain shower came.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: Brief, often heavy rain that comes suddenly. Cultural: '소나기' is the title of a famous Korean short story. Also called 한 줄기 비.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The sound of thunder is scary.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 천둥이 치다 = thunder strikes. Often paired with 번개 (lightning). Collocation: 천둥과 번개 (thunder and lightning).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: Lightning flashed.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 번개가 치다 = lightning strikes. 번쩍 = onomatopoeia for flash. Related: 낙뢰 (lightning strike - formal term).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The car got damaged because hail fell.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: Frozen precipitation that can cause significant damage to vehicles and crops. 우박이 내리다 = hail falls.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The drought is severe this year.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 가물다 = to be dry. 가뭄이 들다 = a drought sets in. Related: 가뭄 피해 (drought damage).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: Frost settled in the morning.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 서리가 내리다 = frost falls/settles. Appears in late autumn and early winter. Related: 서릿발 (frost crystals).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: Dew has formed on the grass blades.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 이슬이 맺히다 = dew forms. Related: 이슬비 = drizzle (dew-rain). Morning dew (아침이슬) - common poetic reference.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The heat wave is intense this summer.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 무 = intensifier + 더위 = heat. 폭염 = the formal/news term. Related: 무더운 날씨 (sweltering weather).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example: 한파가 와서 영하 이십 도까지 내려갔어요.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: A cold wave came and it dropped to minus twenty degrees.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 한 = cold + 파 = wave (Sino-Korean). Often used in winter weather reports. Related: 한파 주의보 (cold wave warning).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The yellow dust was bad so I wore a mask.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 황 = yellow + 사 = sand (Sino-Korean). Blows in from Chinese/Mongolian deserts in spring. Major concern for air quality.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The wind chill temperature is minus ten degrees.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 체감 = perceived/felt + 온도 = temperature. Important in Korean winters as the actual temperature. Check before going outside!

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: Today's high temperature is thirty-five degrees.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 최고 = highest + 기온 = air temperature (Sino-Korean). Used in weather forecasts. Opposite: 최저기온 (daily low).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: Tomorrow's low temperature is minus five degrees.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 최저 = lowest + 기온 = air temperature (Sino-Korean). Usually occurs at dawn/early morning. Plan outfits accordingly!

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The temperature dropped suddenly.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 기 = air + 온 = warmth (Sino-Korean). Korea uses Celsius (섭씨). 기온이 떨어지다 = temperature drops.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: In winter it drops below zero.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 영 = zero + 하 = below (Sino-Korean). 영하 십 도 = minus 10 degrees. Opposite: 영상 (above zero).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: During the day it goes up to five degrees above zero.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 영 = zero + 상 = above (Sino-Korean). 영상 오 도 = 5 degrees above zero. Opposite: 영하.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: I went to the beach to see the sunrise.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 일 = sun + 출 = come out (Sino-Korean). 일출 명소 = famous sunrise spot. Cultural: sunrise viewing is special, especially on holidays.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: Sunset time is getting earlier.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 일 = sun + 몰 = sink (Sino-Korean). 일몰 후 = after sunset. Related: 노을 (glow/sunset colors).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: Let's rest in the shade.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 나무 그늘 = tree shade. 그늘이 지다 = shade falls. Collocation: 시원한 그늘 (cool shade).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: It's warm if you sit in the sunny spot.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 양 = sun + 지 = land (Sino-Korean). Opposite: 음지 (shady spot). 양지를 찾다 = seek sunny spot (also figurative - seek positive things).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: My head hurt so I took medicine.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Means both 'head' and 'hair.' Word family: 머리를 감다 (wash hair), 머리를 자르다 (cut hair), 머리가 나쁘다 (not smart).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I wash my face in the morning.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Word family: 얼굴이 작다 (small face = compliment), 얼굴이 빨개지다 (face turns red/embarrassed), 얼굴을 씻다 (wash face).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: My eyes are tired so I want to rest a bit.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Homonym: also means 'snow.' Related words: 눈물 (tears), 눈동자 (pupil), 눈빛 (gaze). 눈이 크다/작다 describes eye size.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I caught a cold and my nose is stuffed.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Word family: 코를 풀다 (blow nose), 코피 (nosebleed), 콧물 (nasal mucus). 코가 크다/작다 describes nose size.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: Please open your mouth wide.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Word family: 입맛 (appetite), 입술 (lips), 입냄새 (bad breath). 입이 짧다 (picky eater), 입이 크다 (big mouth/talkative).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example: 음악을 너무 크게 들으면 귀가 아파요.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: If you listen to music too loud, your ears hurt.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Word family: 귀걸이 (earring), 귀지 (ear wax), 귓바퀌 (ears). 귀가 밝다 (good hearing), 귀가 어둡다 (hard of hearing).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I brush my teeth three times a day.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 이 is native Korean (casual), 치아 is Sino-Korean (formal). Related: 이를 닦다 (brush teeth), 사랑니 (wisdom tooth), 임플란트 (implant).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: My throat hurts so I can't talk.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Word family: 목도리 (scarf), 목이 마르다 (thirsty = throat is dry), 목이 아프다 (sore throat), 목걸이 (necklace).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: If you use the computer for a long time, your shoulders hurt.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Word family: 어깨가 뻣뻣하다 (stiff shoulders), 어깨 통증 (shoulder pain), 어깨가 넓다 (broad shoulders). Office workers often complain about this.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I exercised a lot so my arms hurt.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Word family: 팔꿈치 (elbow), 팔짱을 끼다 (fold one's arms), 팔을 걷다 (roll up sleeves). Verb form: 팔리다 (to be sold).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I wash my hands before eating.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Word family: 손가락 (finger), 손님 (guest = hand + person), 손잡이 (handle). Collocations: 손을 잡다 (hold hands), 손을 씻다 (wash hands).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I cut my finger while cooking.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 손 (hand) + 가락 (part). Specific fingers: 엄지손가락 (thumb), 검지 (index), 약지 (ring finger), 새끼손가락 (pinky). 손가락질 = pointing (rude gesture).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: When I exercise, my chest pounds.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Word family: 가슴이 두근거리다 (heart races), 가슴이 아프다 (physical or emotional heartache). 가슴팍 = the breast area. Emotional: 마음이 아프다 is more common for heartache.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I'm hungry. Let's go eat!
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Homonym: also means 'boat' or 'pear.' Word family: 배가 고프다 (hungry), 배가 부르다 (full), 배탈 (stomachache), 뱃살 (belly fat).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: If you sit for a long time, your back hurts.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 등 also means 'etc.' in writing. Related words: 등산 (mountain climbing = climbing one's back), 등 근육 (back muscle). 등이 아프다 (back pain) is common.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I hurt my lower back lifting something heavy.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Sino-Korean (虛理). Word family: 허리 통증 (lower back pain, very common), 허리띠 (belt), 허릿살 (waist fat). 허리를 펴다 (straighten back).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I walked a lot so my legs hurt.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Homonym: also means 'bridge.' Word family: 다리를 꼬다 (cross legs), 다리가 길다 (long legs = compliment), 다리 근육 (leg muscle). 다리 통증 is common.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: The new shoes are small so my feet hurt.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Word family: 발가락 (toe), 발목 (ankle), 발톱 (toenail). Cultural note: Koreans remove shoes when entering homes. 발을 불어다 = to warm feet.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I fell and hurt my knee.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Native Korean (not Sino-Korean). Word family: 무릎을 꿇다 (to kneel), 무릎팍 (kneecap area). Knee pain is common among hikers (등산하는 사람). 무릎 관절염 = knee arthritis.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).english: to hurt; to be sick/in pain
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: Where does it hurt?
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Versatile adjective conjugates normally: 아파요 (present), 아팠어요 (past). Collocations: 배가 아프다 (stomach hurts), 마음이 아프다 (heartache), 눈이 아프다 (eyes hurt).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I caught a cold so I'm resting at home.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Native Korean. Verb form: 감기에 걸리다 (catch a cold). Related: 독감 (influenza, more severe), 감기약 (cold medicine). 감기 조심하세요 is a common greeting.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I had a fever so I couldn't go to school.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Native Korean 열 (heat). Verb: 열이 나다 (have a fever). Related: 체온 (body temperature), 37도 = normal, 38도 = fever. 열을 내리다 = to reduce fever.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: My cough won't stop.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Native Korean. Verb: 기침을 하다 (to cough). Related: 기침약 (cough medicine), 기침이 자꾸 나다 (cough keeps coming up). 콘센트를 기침하다 is a play on words.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: My headache was bad so I took medicine.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Sino-Korean: 頭(두=head) + 痛(통=pain). Related words: 두통약 (headache medicine), 편두통 (migraine). Verb: 두통이 있다 (have a headache).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I ate spoiled food and got a stomachache.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 배(stomach) + 탈(ailment). Verb: 배탈이 나다 (get a stomachache). Related: 체하다 (indigestion), 설사 (diarrhea). Collocation: 배탈이 났어요.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: Please take the medicine after eating.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Native Korean. Verb: 약을 먹다 (take medicine = literally 'eat'), 약을 바르다 (apply ointment). Related: 약국 (pharmacy), 처방약 (prescription medicine), 일반의약품 (over-the-counter).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I bought cold medicine at the pharmacy.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 약(medicine) + 국(place). Unique aspect of Korea: many medicines available without prescription. 약사 = pharmacist. 24시간 약국 (24-hour pharmacy) are common.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I was sick so I went to the hospital.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Sino-Korean 病院. Used for any medical facility (clinics, hospitals). Related: 대학병원 (university hospital = large), 응급실 (emergency room), 의원 (small clinic).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: The doctor prescribed medicine for me.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Sino-Korean 醫者(의=medicine, 자=person). Polite form: 의사 선생님. Related: 치과의사 (dentist), 의료진 (medical staff), 의료보험 (health insurance).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: The nurse gave me a shot.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Sino-Korean 看護士(간호=nursing, 사=person). Gender-neutral in Korean. Related: 간호학 (nursing), 간호대학 (nursing college), 간호사 시험 (nursing exam).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I'm relieved the surgery went well.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Sino-Korean 手術. Verb: 수술을 받다 (undergo surgery). Related: 수술실 (operating room), 수술비 (surgery cost), 응급수술 (emergency surgery).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I'm scared of shots.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Native Korean. Verb: 주사를 맞다 (get a shot), 주사를 놓다 (give a shot). Related: 예방주사 (vaccine), 근육주사 (muscle injection), 정맥주사 (IV).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I'm going to the hospital for a health checkup.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Sino-Korean 檢査. Verb: 검사를 받다 (take a test/exam). Related: 혈액 검사 (blood test), 초음파 검사 (ultrasound), 건강검진 (health checkup).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I have a cat allergy.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Loanword from English 'allergy.' Related: 알레르기 증상 (allergy symptoms), 꽃가루 알레르기 (pollen allergy), 음식 알레르기 (food allergy). Verb: 알레르기가 있다.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I exercise every day for my health.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 운동 = exercise/sport (noun). Conjugation: 운동해요 (polite), 운동했어요 (past). Related: 헬스장 (gym), 운동화 (sneakers), 운동선수 (athlete).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: Our grandmother is very healthy.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Sino-Korean 健康. Noun: 건강 (health). Adjective conjugation: 건강해요 (polite), 건강했어요 (past). Common greeting: 건강하게 지내세요 (stay healthy).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I worked a lot today so I'm tired.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Noun: 피곤 = fatigue. Conjugation: 피곤해요 (polite). Related: 피로 (fatigue, formal), 지치다 (exhausted). 너무 피곤해요 is one of Korea's most common complaints.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I couldn't sleep last night.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Native Korean. Collocations: 잠을 자다 (sleep = literally 'sleep + do'), 잠이 오다 (feel sleepy), 잠이 안 오다 (can't sleep), 낮잠 (nap).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I usually sleep at 11 PM.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Verb conjugation: 자요 (polite), 잤어요 (past), 잘 거예요 (future). Honorific: 주무시다 (for elders/respected people). Related: 자리 (sleeping place), 이불 (blanket).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).english: to wake up; to get up
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I wake up at 7 in the morning.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Native Korean 일(起) + 어나다. Has multiple meanings: wake up, stand up, happen/occur. Honorific: 일어나세요! (Wake up!/Stand up!). Related: 일어날 시간 (time to wake up).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example: 혈압이 높으면 소금을 적게 먹어야 해요.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: If your blood pressure is high, you should eat less salt.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Sino-Korean 血(혈=blood) + 壓(압=pressure). Related: 고혈압 (high blood pressure), 저혈압 (low blood pressure), 혈압계 (blood pressure monitor). Verb: 혈압을 재다 (measure blood pressure).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example: 당뇨가 있으면 단 음식을 조심해야 해요.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: If you have diabetes, you need to be careful with sweet foods.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Sino-Korean 糖(당=sugar) + 尿(뇨=urine). Full term: 당뇨병 (diabetes disease). Very common health concern. Related: 당뇨 검사 (diabetes test), 혈당 (blood sugar).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example: 이 병은 치료가 가능해요. 걱정하지 마세요.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: This illness is treatable. Don't worry.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Sino-Korean 治(치=govern) + 療(료=heal). Verb: 치료하다 (treat/cure), 치료를 받다 (receive treatment). Related: 치료비 (treatment cost), 진료 (medical consultation).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I got a prescription from the doctor.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Sino-Korean 處(처) + 方(방) + 箋(전). Korean system: get prescription from doctor, take it to pharmacy. Related: 처방약 (prescription medicine), 처방하다 (prescribe).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example: 어떤 증상이 있어요? 자세히 말해 주세요.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: What symptoms do you have? Please tell me in detail.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Sino-Korean 症(증=disease) + 狀(상=condition). Common question at doctor: 증상이 언제부터 시작됐어요? (When did symptoms start?). Related: 증상이 나타나다 (symptoms appear).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: My body temperature is 38 degrees. I have a fever.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Sino-Korean 體(체=body) + 溫(온=warmth). Normal ~36.5°C. Verb: 체온을 재다 (take temperature). Related: 체온계 (thermometer), 정상 체온 (normal temperature).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example: 밥을 너무 빨리 먹으면 소화가 안 돼요.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: If you eat too fast, you can't digest well.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Sino-Korean 消(소=dissolve) + 化(화=transform). Related: 소화가 잘 되다 (digest well), 소화가 안 되다 (indigestion), 소화제 (digestive medicine), 소화 기관 (digestive system).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: If your immunity is weak, you easily catch colds.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Sino-Korean 免(면=exempt) + 疫(역=disease). Related: 면역력 (immune strength), 면역 체계 (immune system). Health-conscious Koreans focus on boosting 면역력.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example: 요즘 스트레스를 많이 받아요. 쉬고 싶어요.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I'm very stressed lately. I want to rest.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Loanword from English 'stress.' Very commonly used in Korean daily life. Collocations: 스트레스를 받다 (feel stress), 스트레스를 풀다 (relieve stress). Related: 스트레스 관리 (stress management).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I take vitamins every day. They're good for health.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Loanword from English 'vitamin.' Popular in Korea. Related: 종합비타민 (multivitamin), 비타민C, 비타민D. Verb: 비타민을 먹다 (take vitamins).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I'm on a diet, so I eat less for dinner.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Loanword: 다이어트 = weight loss (not general eating). Verb: 다이어트하다 (to diet). Related: 다이어트 식품 (diet food), 다이어트 중 (on a diet). Very popular topic in Korea.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I gained weight. I need to start exercising.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Sino-Korean 體(체=body) + 重(중=weight). Related: 체중이 늘다 (gain weight), 체중이 줄다 (lose weight), 체중계 (scale), 표준 체중 (ideal weight).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: How tall are you? I'm 170cm.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Native Korean. Measurement: 센티미터 (centimeters). Collocations: 키가 크다 (tall), 키가 작다 (short), 키가 비슷하다 (same height). 키가 몇이에요? is a common question.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: If you have good stamina, you don't get tired.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Sino-Korean 體(체=body) + 力(력=strength). Related: 체력이 좋다/나쁘다 (have good/bad stamina), 체력을 키우다 (build stamina), 체력 운동 (strength training).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I get a health checkup every year. It's important.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 건강(health) + 검진(examination). In Korea, employers provide annual 건강검진 for employees (legally required). Related: 종합건강검진 (comprehensive checkup), 검진 결과 (checkup results).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I take the bus to school every day.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Loanword from English. Related: 시내버스 (city bus), 고속버스 (express bus), 마을버스 (village bus), 버스 정류장 (bus stop), 버스 기사 (bus driver).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: In Seoul, the subway is the most convenient.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 지하(underground) + 철(rail). Also called 전철. Seoul's system is color-coded by line number (1호선-9호선). Related: 지하철역 (subway station), 환승역 (transfer station).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I was late so I took a taxi.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Loanword from English 'taxi.' Related: 모범택시 (deluxe taxi = black, expensive), 콜택시 (call taxi = app-based), 택시 미터 (taxi meter), 택시비 (taxi fare).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: It takes two hours to arrive by airplane.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 비행(flight) + 기(machine). Related: 비행기를 타다 (take a plane), 비행기표 (plane ticket), 탑승권 (boarding pass), 공항 (airport).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I want to go to Busan by train.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Native Korean. Types: KTX (고속열차=high-speed), 무궁화호 (regular train), 통근열차 (commuter train). Related: 기차역 (train station), 기차표 (train ticket), 승차권 (boarding ticket).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I went to Jeju Island by boat.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Homonym: also means 'stomach' or 'pear.' Related: 여객선 (passenger ship), 유람선 (cruise ship), 배표 (boat ticket), 배 여행 (boat trip).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I ride a bicycle in the park.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 자(self) + 전(electric) + 거(vehicle). Verb: 자전거를 타다 (ride a bicycle). Related: 따릉이 (Seoul's public bike), 자전거 도로 (bike lane), 자전거 여행 (bike tour).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I want to buy a new car.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 자동차 = formal, 차 = casual (much more common). 차 also means 'tea.' Related: 차를 사다 (buy a car), 차를 끌다 (tow a car), 승용차 (passenger car).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: There are really many delivery motorcycles.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Loanword from English 'auto-bike.' Very common for 배달(delivery) in Korea. Related: 오토바이를 타다 (ride motorcycle), 오토바이 사고 (motorcycle accident).

교통 (Transportation).example: 여기서 몇 번 버스를 타야 해요?
교통 (Transportation).example_en: What number bus should I take here?
교통 (Transportation).notes: Verb for all vehicles. Conjugation: 타요 (polite), 탔어요 (past), 탈 거예요 (future). Also means 'to burn.' Related: 버스를 타다, 지하철을 타다, 택시를 타다.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I get off at the next stop.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Verb for getting off vehicles/descending. Conjugation: 내려요 (polite), 내렸어요 (past). Related meanings: 비가 내리다 (rain falls), 눈이 내리다 (snow falls).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Transfer from Line 2 to Line 3.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 갈다(change) + 타다(ride). Verb: 갈아타다. Noun: 환승(transfer). Related: 환승역 (transfer station), 무료 환승 (free transfer within 30 minutes).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I booked the ticket in advance.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Native Korean (票 in hanja). Related: 승차권 (formal transport ticket), 왕복표 (round-trip ticket), 편도표 (one-way ticket), 표를 끊다 (buy a ticket).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: How much is the bus fare?
교통 (Transportation).notes: Sino-Korean 要(요=necessary) + 金(금=money). Related: 기본요금 (base fare), 추가요금 (additional charge), 요금 인상 (fare increase), 환승 요금 (transfer fee).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I need to charge money on my transit card.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 교통(transportation) + 카드(card). Brand: T-money (most common). Verb: 충전하다 (recharge/charge). Related: 카드 잔액 (card balance), 충전소 (charging station).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Drive carefully!
교통 (Transportation).notes: Noun form. Related: 운전면허 (driver's license), 운전면허증 (license card), 운전 기술 (driving skill), 운전자 (driver).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I like driving.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Verb form. Conjugation: 운전해요 (polite), 운전했어요 (past). Related: 음주운전 (drunk driving = serious in Korea), 초보운전 (beginner driver).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Can I park here?
교통 (Transportation).notes: Noun form. Related: 주차금지 (no parking), 주차비 (parking fee), 주차 위반 (parking violation), 주차하다 (to park).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: The parking lot is full.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 주차(parking) + 장(place). Related: 지하주차장 (underground parking), 실외주차장 (outdoor parking), 주차 공간 (parking space). Often abbreviated as 'P' on signs.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: What time do you arrive at the airport?
