외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I dyed my hair brown.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 한자어: 染 (dye) + 色 (color). Related: 염색하다 (dye), 셀프 염색 (DIY). Common: 갈색으로 염색하다.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: Getting a perm totally changed the vibe.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Loanword (permanent wave). Related: 파마를 하다 (get perm), 볼륨 파마. Common: 파마 스타일.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I've gotten a few wrinkles around my eyes.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Native word. Related: 주름살, 주름을 펴다 (smooth). Korean: anti-wrinkle products huge.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I have a mole next to my nose.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Native word (also means dot/point). Related: 점을 빼다 (remove mole), 점의 위치. Cultural: 위치별 의미 있음.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example: 어렸을 때 다쳐서 팔에 흉터가 있어요.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I have a scar on my arm from getting hurt as a child.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 한자어: 凶 (ugly/bad) + 터 (mark/place). Related: 흉터 치료 (treatment), 흉터 연고. Common: 흉터를 없애다.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example: 요즘 한국에서도 문신을 하는 사람이 많아요.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: These days, many people in Korea also get tattoos.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 한자어: 文 (pattern) + 身 (body). Also: 타투. Cultural: Korea legally doctors only; widely debated.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: Everyone has a different body type.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 한자어: 體 (body) + 形 (type). Related: 상체 (upper body), 하체 (lower body). Common: 체형에 맞는 옷.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example: 너무 말라서 살을 좀 찌우고 싶어요.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I'm so skinny that I want to gain some weight.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Native verb (irregular). Conjugation: 마르다→말라요. Related: 살이 빠지다 (lose weight). Common: 살을 찌우고 싶어요.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: The baby's cheeks are chubby and cute.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Native adjective. Related: 통통한 뺨 (chubby cheeks). Softer, cuter than 뚱뚱하다. Often affectionate.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I've become slim from exercising.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Native adjective. Related: 날씬한 몸매 (slim figure), 몸매가 좋다. Common: Korean compliment.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: That person is tall and well-built.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 한자어: 健 (healthy) + 壯 (strong). Related: 건장한 체격 (sturdy build). Usually male descriptor.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example: 그 사람은 옷을 항상 세련되게 입어요.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: That person always dresses stylishly.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 한자어: 洗 (refine) + 煉 (practice). Related: 세련된 스타일 (sophisticated). Opposite: 촌스럽다.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example: 이 디자인이 좀 촌스러운 것 같아요.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I think this design is a bit tacky.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Native adjective (from 촌 village/rural). Related: 촌스러운 패션 (unfashionable). Opposite: 세련되다.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: That color really suits you.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Native verb. Related: 어울려요 (suits you), 안 어울려요 (doesn't suit). Very common about appearance.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I often wear warm knit sweaters in winter.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Loanword (English 'knit'). Related: 니트 스웨터, 따뜻한 니트. Common: 겨울 따뜻한 니트.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I wear a hoodie when I want to be comfortable.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Loanword: 후드 (hood) + 티 (t-shirt). Related: 후드집업 (zip-up hoodie). Common: 편한 후드티.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I drape a cardigan over my shoulders in spring.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Loanword (English 'cardigan'). Related: 카디건을 걸치다 (drape). Common: 봄/가을 겹겹이 입기.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: Wearing a vest with a suit looks cool.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Native word. Related: 정장 조끼 (formal vest), 구명조끼 (life vest). Common: 등산 조끼.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I'm going to a cafe to meet a friend.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 친한 친구 (close friend), 절친 (best friend), 같은 반 친구 (classmate). Collocations: 친구하고 놀다 (hang out), 친구를 사귀다 (make a friend).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: My boyfriend is really good at cooking.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Literally '남자(男子, male) + 친구(friend).' Abbreviated 남친 (casual). Related: 여자친구 (girlfriend), 배우자 (spouse).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example: 여자친구 생일 선물을 아직 못 샀어요.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I haven't bought a birthday gift for my girlfriend yet.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Literally '여자(女子, female) + 친구(friend).' Abbreviated 여친 (casual). Related: 남자친구 (boyfriend).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: My senior bought me lunch.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 선(先, first/earlier) + 배(輩, generation). Important in Korean hierarchy; seniors often mentor and treat juniors. Related: 후배 (junior).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I gave advice to my juniors.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Counterpart of 선배. Juniors show respect through 존댓말 and accept guidance. Collocations: 후배를 챙기다 (look after a junior), 후배에게 대접하다.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: When a neighbor moves in, you greet them.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: In Korean apartments, gifting small items like 화장지 (toilet paper), 세제 (detergent) to new neighbors is customary. Collocations: 이웃 주민, 옆집 이웃.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: A guest is coming to our house today.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Used for both house guests and customers. Related: 고객 (customer, formal), 방문객 (visitor). Collocation: 손님을 대접하다 (treat a guest).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example: 그 사람은 아는 사람이에요. 친구는 아니에요.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: That person is an acquaintance. Not a friend.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Literal: '아는(knowing) 사람(person).' Koreans distinguish clearly between 친구 (true friends) and casual 아는 사람. Related: 지인.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example: 낯선 사람한테 말을 걸면 안 돼요.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: You shouldn't talk to strangers.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 낯설다 (unfamiliar/strange), 사람 (person). Related: 모르는 사람 (unknown person). Common phrase: '낯선 사람한테 ついていかない.'

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I have plans with a friend tomorrow.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 약(約, agreement) + 속(束, binding). Collocations: 약속을 지키다 (keep a promise), 약속을 잡다 (make plans), 약속을 어기다 (break a promise).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: My friend set me up on a blind date.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 소개(introduction) + 미팅(meeting, from English). Very common dating method in Korea. Related: 소개 (introduction), 미팅 (meeting).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I'm going on a date with my boyfriend this weekend.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Borrowed from English 'date.' 100일 (100th day anniversary), 1000일 (1000th day) are celebrated milestones in Korean dating culture.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I don't have time for dating these days.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 연(戀, romantic love) + 애(愛, love). Collocations: 연애하다 (be in a relationship), 연애를 하다, 연애 경험 (dating experience).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I'm going to my older sister's wedding next month.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 결혼(marriage) + 식(ceremony). Korean weddings are brief (~30 min). Guests give 축의금 (monetary gift) in white envelope. Related: 혼례 (formal wedding).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: Happy birthday! (Congratulations on your birthday!)
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 축(祝, blessing) + 하다 (to do). Related phrases: 축하해요 (casual), 축하드립니다 (formal). Collocations: 생일 축하, 합격 축하.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I invited friends to my birthday party.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 초대(inviting) + 하다. Related: 초대장 (invitation card), 초대 손님 (invited guest). Collocations: 파티에 초대하다, 집에 초대하다.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I visit my grandmother's house on weekends.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 방문(visiting) + 하다. More formal than 가다 or 놀러 가다. Related: 방문객 (visitor), 방문 예약 (appointment/reservation).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: What do you want to receive as a birthday present?
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 선물하다 (to give as a gift, verb form). Koreans prefer practical gifts. Collocations: 생일 선물, 크리스마스 선물, 선물을 포장하다 (wrap a gift).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: When you meet an elder, you greet them first.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 인사(greeting/bow) + 하다. In Korea, a slight bow accompanies greetings. Related: 인사말 (greeting), 인사를 나누다 (exchange greetings).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: We met for the first time and shook hands.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 악(握, to grasp) + 수(手, hand). When shaking hands with elders, support right arm with left hand as a sign of respect. Traditional Korean greeting.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: We met after a long time and hugged.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 포옹하다 (to hug, verb). Less common in Korea than in Western cultures, especially between men. Reserved for close relationships.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: You use formal speech with people you meet for the first time.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 존댓말 is essential Korean politeness. Related: 반말 (informal), 존경 (respect). Collocations: 존댓말을 쓰다, 존댓말로 말하다.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I use casual speech with close friends.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Switching from 존댓말 to 반말 marks deepening relationships. Koreans typically ask: '말 놓을까요?' (Shall we be casual?) Related: 존댓말.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: Manners are very important in Korea.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 예의(禮儀) comes from Confucian tradition. Related: 예의 바르다 (be polite), 예의 없다 (be rude). Collocations: 예의를 지키다 (observe etiquette).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: It's important to be considerate of others.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 배려(consideration) is highly valued in Korean society. Related: 배려심 (considerate nature), 배려하다 (to be considerate).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: When you make a mistake, apologize right away.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 사과(謝過) + 하다. Note: 사과 also means 'apple' (context matters). Apology phrases: 미안해요, 죄송해요, 용서해 주세요.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I'm really grateful that my friend forgave me.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 용서(容恕, forgiveness) + 하다. Stronger than a simple apology. Related: 용서를 구하다 (ask for forgiveness).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: If you need help, please tell me.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 도움(help, noun). Related verbs: 돕다 (to help), 도움을 주다 (provide help), 도움을 받다 (receive help).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: Can I ask you just one favor?
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 부탁(部託) + 하다 (verb form). 부탁드리다 is humble/polite. Key phrase: 잘 부탁드려요 (asking for cooperation/help).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I'm sorry, but I have to decline that request.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 거절(拒絕) + 하다. Koreans soften refusals: '좀 어려울 것 같아요' (That might be difficult). Indirect refusal is more polite.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I agree with that opinion too.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 동의(同意) + 하다. Related: 찬성하다 (to approve/agree), 동의하지 않아요 (I disagree). Formal: 동의합니다.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: My parents oppose that plan.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 반대(反對) + 하다. Related: 반대 (opposition, noun), 반대쪽 (opposite side). Collocations: 반대 의견, 반대하지 않다.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I want to hear everyone's opinions.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 의견(意見). Collocations: 의견을 내다 (give an opinion), 의견이 다르다 (have different opinions), 다양한 의견.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: Let's discuss this topic together.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 토론(討論) + 하다. More formal/structured than 이야기하다 or 대화하다. Related: 토론회 (discussion meeting).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: That's a misunderstanding. Let me explain.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 오해(誤解, misunderstanding). Collocations: 오해하다 (to misunderstand), 오해를 풀다 (clear up misunderstanding).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: We made up quickly after fighting.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 화해(和解) + 하다. Often used after conflicts between friends, couples, or family. Related: 화해의 악수 (reconciliation handshake).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).english: to get along well; to be on good terms
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: Everyone in our family gets along well.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Usually 사이가 좋다 (with subject particle). Related: 사이가 나쁘다 (not getting along), 좋은 사이 (good relationship).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I had a fight with my friend yesterday.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Can mean physical fighting or verbal arguing. Related: 다투다 (quarrel, softer), 싸움 (noun: fight). Collocation: 싸우다가 화해하다.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).english: to break up; to part ways
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I broke up with my boyfriend last month.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 헤어지다 used for romantic breakups and parting after meeting. Context determines meaning. Collocation: 헤어지다고 통보하다 (break up by telling).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).english: to date someone; to go out with
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: The two of them have been dating for 6 months.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 사귀다 means official relationship, unlike casual dating. How Koreans ask out: 사귀자 (Let's date). Related: 사귀는 사람 (partner).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).english: to contact; to get in touch
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I'll contact you later.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 연락(contact) covers calls, texts, messages. Related: 연락이 안 되다 (unreachable), 연락처 (contact info). Collocation: 연락하자 (let's stay in touch).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I heard news about my friend after a long time.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 소식(소食?, personal news about someone, unlike 뉴스 (broadcast news). Collocations: 소식을 전하다 (deliver news), 소식이 없다 (no word).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: Please give my regards to your parents.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 안부(安否, well-being). Warm, polite expression used in Korean culture. Collocations: 안부를 묻다 (ask after someone), 안부 인사.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: There's a university festival this weekend.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 축제(祝祭). Korean university festivals (대학 축제) feature performances and food. Collocations: 축제 분위기, 지역 축제, 봄 축제.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example: 이번 주 금요일에 파티에 갈 거예요.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I'm going to a party this Friday.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Borrowed from English 'party.' Koreans celebrate more often at restaurants/PC방/노래방 than house parties. Related: 생일 파티, 파티복.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I ran into a high school classmate by chance yesterday.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 동(同, same) + 창(窗, window=school). Related: 동창회 (alumni reunion), 동창생 (fellow alumni). Collocation: 동창 만남.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I still keep in touch with my childhood friend.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 소꿉(children's house-playing) + 친구. 소꿉놀이 (children playing house). A cherished bond in Korean culture.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: We've been best friends for over 10 years.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 베프 from English 'BFF.' 절친 = 절친한 친구 (very close friend). Both casual, popular with younger Koreans. Related: 단짝.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: That person is a work acquaintance.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 지(知, know) + 인(人, person). More formal than 아는 사람. Related: 지인 소개 (introduction through acquaintance).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: It's important to meet a good mentor.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Loanword from English. Related: 멘티 (mentee), 멘토링 (mentoring). The 멘토-멘티 relationship is valued in Korean work culture.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).english: benefactor / someone you owe gratitude to
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: That person is my life's benefactor.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 은(恩, grace/kindness) + 인(人, person). 생명의 은인 (life savior) is emotionally strong. A deeply respectful term in Korean.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: That athlete is a long-time rival.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Loanword from English. Can be positive (healthy competition) or negative. Related: 라이벌 관계 (rivalry), 경쟁자 (competitor).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I'm a passionate fan of that singer.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Loanword from English. Related: 팬클럽 (fan club), 응원봉 (light stick), 팬심 (fan devotion). Korea has highly organized idol fan culture.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I made a library membership card.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 회(會, association) + 원(員, person). Collocations: 회원 가입 (membership registration), 회원증 (membership card).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I got a Korean language proficiency certificate.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 자격(自格, qualification) + 증(證, proof). Collocations: 자격증을 따다 (earn a certificate), 자격증 준비. Koreans collect multiple 자격증 for career advancement.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I do volunteer work every Saturday.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 봉사(奉仕) = volunteering, service. Related: 봉사활동 (volunteer activity), 봉사자 (volunteer). Korean students need 봉사 hours for school records.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I donated for neighbors in need.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 기부(寄付, donation) + 하다. Related: 기부금 (donation money), 기부 문화 (donation culture), 연말 기부 (year-end donations).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I went to vote on election day.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 투표(投票) + 하다. Related: 투표소 (polling station), 투표율 (voter turnout). Korea holds presidential elections every 5 years.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: Tax is deducted from my salary.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 세(稅, tax) + 금(金, money). Types: 소득세 (income tax), 부가가치세 (VAT). Collocations: 세금을 내다 (pay taxes), 세금 환급.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: It's important to follow the law.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 법(法). More formal: 법률. Related: 법원 (court), 변호사 (lawyer), 법조인 (legal professional). Collocations: 법을 어기다 (break the law).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: You must follow the classroom rules well.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 규(規, standard) + 칙(則, rule). Related: 규정 (formal regulations), 법칙 (principle). Collocations: 규칙을 지키다, 규칙을 어기다.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: Citizens gathered for environmental protection.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 시(市, city) + 민(民, people). Related: 시민권 (citizenship), 시민의식 (civic consciousness), 시민단체 (civic organization).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: All people have equal rights.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 권(權, power/authority) + 리(利, benefit). Collocations: 인권 (human rights), 권리를 행사하다 (exercise rights), 기본권 (fundamental rights).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: Paying taxes is a citizen's duty.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 의(義, righteousness) + 무(務, duty). 의무적 = obligatory/mandatory. 국방의 의무 = military service duty (Korean men must serve ~2 years).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: Gender equality is a very important value.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 평(平, flat/equal) + 등(等, grade/rank). Related: 평등하다 (to be equal), 불평등 (inequality), 성평등 (gender equality).

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Is anyone there? Help!
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: Most important emergency phrase. Related: 살려 주세요! (Save me! for life-threatening situations), 도와주다 (to help someone).

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: It's dangerous if you go there! Be careful!
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 위험(危險) + 하다. Related: 위험 (noun), 위험물 (hazardous material). Collocations: 위험 신호, 위험하다, 조심하세요!

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Fire! Get out quickly!
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: Shouted in 반말 even in emergencies (speed > politeness). Related: 불 (fire, noun), 불을 피우다 (make a fire).

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: We need to report it to the police.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 경찰(警察). Related: 경찰서 (police station), 경찰관 (police officer), 경찰차 (police car). Emergency: dial 112 in Korea.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: The firefighters put out the fire quickly.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 소방(消防) + 관(官, officer). Related: 소방서 (fire station), 소방차 (fire truck), 소방 안전. Korean firefighters handle medical emergencies too.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Please call an ambulance quickly!
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 구급(救急, emergency) + 차(車, vehicle). Collocation: 구급차를 부르다 (call ambulance). In Korea, dial 119 for fire/ambulance.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: If there's an accident, call 119.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: Korea's emergency number for fire and medical services, available 24/7. International visitors should memorize: 119 (emergency), 112 (police).

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: If you saw a thief, report it to 112.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 한국 경찰 긴급 번호. For non-emergency police, visit local 경찰서 (police station).

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: There was a traffic accident on the road.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 사고(事故). Types: 교통사고 (traffic accident), 산업재해 (industrial accident). Collocations: 사고가 나다 (accident occurs), 사고를 당하다.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: If you're sick at night, go to the emergency room.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 응급(應急) + 실(室, room). Korean hospitals usually have 24-hour emergency rooms. Related: 응급 환자 (emergency patient).

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: A thief stole my wallet.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 도둑(도둑). Related: 소매치기 (pickpocket), 강도 (robber, more violent), 도둑질 (theft). Collocations: 도둑을 잡다 (catch a thief).

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: I went to the lost and found center and asked.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 분실(分失) = lost/loss. Related: 분실물 (lost item), 분실 신고 (lost report). Korea has excellent lost & found, especially on public transit.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: I lost my phone on the subway.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: For losing objects only. 길을 잃다 = to get lost (directionally). 잃다 (more literary). Collocation: 잃어버린 물건.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: I found the bag I lost!
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 찾다 means both 'search for' and 'find.' Context determines. 찾아보다 emphasizes searching effort. Collocation: 길을 찾다 (find the way).

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: If you see a suspicious person, please report it.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 신고(申告) + 하다. Used for reporting to police, fire dept, etc. Related: 신고 접수 (report received), 신고 전화.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: If there's an earthquake, evacuate outside.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 대피(待避) + 하다. Related: 대피소 (shelter), 대피 훈련 (evacuation drill). Critical during natural disasters.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Check the location of the emergency exit in advance.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 비상(非常, emergency) + 구(口, opening/exit). Green signs mark 비상구. Required in all public buildings in Korea.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: You need to know how to use a fire extinguisher.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 소화(消化, extinguish) + 기(機, device). Red fire extinguishers placed in hallways of Korean buildings for public safety.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: There was a small earthquake last night.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 지진(地震). Collocation: 지진이 나다 (earthquake occurs). Korea experiences occasional quakes; 2017 Pohang earthquake raised awareness significantly.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: It rained a lot and there was a flood.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 홍수(洪水). Related: 홍수 주의보 (flood warning), 장마철 (rainy season). Korea's monsoon in summer brings heavy flooding risks.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: There was a power outage because of the typhoon.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 정전(停電) + 되다. Colloquial: 전기가 나가다 (lights go out). Related: 정전 사태 (blackout incident).

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: The elevator broke down.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 고장(故障) + 나다. Collocations: 고장 수리 (repair), '고장' sign = 'out of order.' Common: 엘리베이터 고장, TV 고장.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: I signed up for insurance before my trip.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 보험(保險). Types: 여행자 보험 (travel insurance), 건강 보험 (health insurance). Korea has national health insurance system (국민건강보험).

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Make sure to bring your passport.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 여권(旅券). Collocations: 여권 번호 (passport number), 여권을 갱신하다 (renew passport). Keep it safe while traveling in Korea.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: You need a visa to study in Korea.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 비자(visa, transliteration). Types: 관광 비자 (tourist visa), 학생 비자 (student visa). Collocations: 비자를 받다, 비자를 신청하다.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Please show me your ID.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 신분증(身分證). Korean citizens get 주민등록증 (resident registration card) at age 17. Foreigners carry 외국인등록증.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: If you lose your passport, go to the consulate.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 영사관(領事館). Related: 대사관 (embassy, in capital). Both can help citizens abroad. Important for travelers.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: I need Korean interpretation.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 통역(通譯) + 하다. Related: 통역사 (interpreter), 통역 서비스. Distinct from 번역 (written translation).

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Please translate this document into English.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 번역(翻譯) + 하다. Related: 번역가 (translator), 번역 앱. For documents/text, unlike 통역 (spoken).

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).english: to make an appointment; to set up plans
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: I made an appointment at the hospital.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 약속(약속, appointment) + 잡다 (to set/grab). Also used casually for making plans with friends. Related: 약속 시간.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: I'll make a reservation at the restaurant before going.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 예약(預約) + 하다. Collocations: 예약이 꽉 찼어요 (fully booked), 예약을 취소하다 (cancel reservation).

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: I canceled my plans because it rained.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 취소(取消) + 하다. Related: 취소 수수료 (cancellation fee). Collocations: 주문을 취소하다, 예약을 취소하다.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: I want to change my flight date.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 변경(變更) + 하다. More formal than 바꾸다. Related: 일정 변경 (schedule change), 변경 예정.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Please confirm the reservation one more time.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 확인(確認) + 하다. Very common. Collocations: 확인했어요 (I confirmed), 확인 부탁 (please verify).

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Please sign here.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 서명(署名) + 하다. Also: 사인 (from English 'sign,' casual). 도장 (stamp/seal) often used alongside signatures in Korea.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: It's good to learn first aid methods.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 응급(應急, emergency) + 처치(處置, treatment). Related: 응급처치 키트 (first aid kit), 응급처치 교육.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Do you know how to perform CPR?
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 심폐(心肺, heart & lungs) + 소생술(蘇生術, resuscitation). Often abbreviated as CPR even in Korean.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Please wrap the wound with a bandage.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 붕대 + 감다 (wrap/wind). Collocation: 붕대를 감다 is standard. 반창고 = adhesive bandage/band-aid.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Apply disinfectant to the wound first.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 소독(消毒) + 약(藥, medicine). Related: 소독하다 (to disinfect), 알코올 소독약.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: They move the patient on a stretcher.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 들다 (carry) + 것 (thing). Used by paramedics and in hospitals. Related: 응급차 (ambulance).

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: What's your blood type? I'm type A.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 혈액(血液, blood) + 형(型, type). In Korea, blood type is discussed like zodiac signs, believed to relate to personality.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example: 수술 중에 수혈이 필요할 수 있어요.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: A blood transfusion may be needed during surgery.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 수(輸, receive/give) + 혈(血, blood). Collocation: 수혈하다 (to transfuse), 수혈 가능 (transfusion possible).

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: My father was hospitalized.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 입원(入院). Collocation: 입원하다 (to be hospitalized), 입원 기간. Opposite: 퇴원 (discharge).

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: They said I can be discharged next week.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 퇴원(退院). Related: 퇴원하다 (to be discharged), 퇴원 날짜. Opposite: 입원.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: After the test, I was diagnosed with a cold.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 진단(診斷). Collocations: 진단하다 (diagnose), 진단받다 (be diagnosed), 진단서 (medical certificate).

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: The doctor gave me a prescription.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 처방(處方) + 하다. Related: 처방전 (prescription paper). Collocation: 처방약 (prescription drug).

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example: 이 약은 부작용이 있을 수 있어요.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: This medication may have side effects.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 부작용(副作用). Common question at pharmacies: 부작용이 있어요? (Are there side effects?)

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: This area is off-limits.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 금지(禁止) + 하다. Common signs: 주차 금지 (no parking), 촬영 금지 (no photography), 흡연 금지 (no smoking).

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Be careful because it's slippery.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 주의(注意) + 하다. Common: 주의하다 (be careful). Seen on warning signs and safety announcements.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: You cannot bring hazardous materials onto the plane.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 위험(危險) + 물(物, material/thing). Collocation: 위험물 취급 주의 (handle hazardous materials with care).

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I wear hanbok on Lunar New Year.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 한(韓, Korean) + 복(服, clothing). Worn now mainly on holidays. Many tourists rent hanbok near 경복궁 for photos and free entry.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: We make kimchi before winter comes.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 김(gimchi making) + 장(making). Families/communities gather in November. UNESCO recognized it as cultural heritage. Related: 김치 (kimchi).

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: We eat rice cake soup on the morning of Lunar New Year.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 떡(rice cake) + 국(soup). Eating 떡국 on 설날 symbolizes gaining a year; sliced rice cakes resemble coins (prosperity). Traditional breakfast.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: We make songpyeon together with family on Chuseok.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 송편 = half-moon shaped rice cakes filled with 깨(sesame), 팥(beans), or 밤(chestnuts). Made together as family tradition during 추석.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: We bow to our elders for the New Year.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 세배(歲拜) = deep bow on 설날 to show respect to elders. After bowing, elders give wisdom, blessings, and 세뱃돈 (money).

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I bowed and received New Year's money.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 세배(세배) + 돈(money). Money given by elders to children/young people after 세배. Usually given in clean, crisp new bills.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: On Chuseok, we go to our hometown.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 추석 = August 15 (lunar calendar). One of Korea's biggest holidays. Families gather, visit ancestral graves (성묘), share food. Expect heavy traffic.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: The whole family gathers on Lunar New Year.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 설날 = January 1 (lunar calendar). One of Korea's two most important holidays with 추석. 3-day holiday period. Related: 구정 (old New Year's Day).

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example: 한글날은 한글을 만든 것을 기념하는 날이에요.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Hangul Day is a day to celebrate the creation of Hangul.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 한글날 = celebrates King Sejong's creation of 한글 in 1443. National holiday since 2013. Related: 한글 (Korean alphabet).

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: We give carnations to our parents on Parents' Day.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 어버이(parents) + 날(day). Unlike Western countries with separate Mother's/Father's Days, Korea celebrates both on one day. Traditional gift: 카네이션 (carnation).

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: We go to the amusement park on Children's Day.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 어린이(children) + 날(day). National holiday where parents spend day with children. Amusement parks, zoos, and kid places are very crowded.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: There are many beautiful hanok in Bukchon.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 한(Korean) + 옥(house). Traditional houses with curved roofs and 온돌 (heated floors). Famous villages: 북촌한옥마을, 전주한옥마을.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example: 한국 집에는 온돌이 있어서 바닥이 따뜻해요.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Korean houses have ondol so the floor is warm.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 온돌 = traditional Korean heating system where hot air flows under the floor. Modern apartments still use this system. Koreans sit/sleep on heated floors.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I spent a night at the jjimjilbang with friends.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 찜질방 = large public bathhouse with saunas, heated rooms, common areas. Open 24 hours; popular overnight. Wear provided shorts and t-shirt.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: We went to karaoke after the company dinner.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 노래(song) + 방(room) = private singing room. Staple of Korean nightlife/socializing. 코인노래방 = coin-operated machine for solo singing.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Having chicken and beer at the Han River is the best.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 치맥 = 치킨(chicken) + 맥주(beer) combined. Beloved Korean combo, especially outdoors along Han River. Cultural phenomenon.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Shall I make you a glass of somaek?
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 소맥 = 소주(soju) + 맥주(beer) mixed. Popular Korean drinking style. Ideal ratio debated, but 3:7 (soju:beer) common.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: In Korea, anything can be delivered.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 배달 = delivery service. Korea has advanced delivery culture. Food/groceries delivered quickly via 배달의민족, 쿠팡이츠 apps.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I bought a triangle kimbap at the convenience store.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 편의(convenience) + 점(store). Extremely high density in Korea: CU, GS25, 세븐일레븐. Sell meals, snacks, have seating areas.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: People with quick nunchi are popular.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 눈치 = ability to read atmosphere and others' feelings. Core Korean social concept. 눈치가 빠르다 = good (good at reading room), 눈치가 없다 = bad.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: We've worked together a long time, so I've developed jeong.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 정(情, affection) = untranslatable Korean concept. Deep emotional bond from shared experience. 정이 들다, 정이 많다. Uniquely Korean value.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: It's important to show filial piety to your parents.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 효도(孝道) from Confucian tradition. Related: 효도하다 (practice filial piety), 효자 (devoted son), 효녀 (devoted daughter).

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: In Korea, the senior-junior culture is strong.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 선후배 = 선배(senior) + 후배(junior). Hierarchical system based on age/experience in school/work. Seniors guide juniors.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: There's a company dinner tonight.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 회식(會食) = after-work team dinners, often multiple rounds (1차, 2차, 3차). Traditionally somewhat mandatory; becoming more optional in modern workplaces.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I rode a bicycle at Han River Park on the weekend.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 한강 = river flowing through Seoul with beautiful parks on both banks. Popular for 피크닉, cycling, delivery food (한강 피크닉).

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I saw the Seoul night view from Namsan Tower.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: Iconic Seoul landmark on Namsan Mountain. Famous for observation deck and 'love locks' on fence (couples' tradition).

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I took photos wearing hanbok at Gyeongbokgung.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 경복궁 = main royal palace of Joseon dynasty (built 1395). Free entry if wearing 한복. Guard-changing ceremony is popular attraction.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example: 제주도는 한국에서 가장 인기 있는 여행지예요.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Jeju Island is the most popular travel destination in Korea.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 제주도 = volcanic island off southern Korea. Famous for 한라산(Hallasan), 돌하르방(stone statues), nature. UNESCO World Heritage site.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example: 경주에 가면 불국사에 꼭 가 보세요.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: If you go to Gyeongju, definitely visit Bulguksa.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 불국사 = UNESCO World Heritage Buddhist temple in Gyeongju (built 774). One of Korea's most famous historical sites, representing Silla dynasty.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Samulnori performances are really exciting.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 사물놀이 = traditional percussion using four instruments: 꽹과리(small gong), 징(large gong), 장구(hourglass drum), 북(barrel drum).

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Pansori is a UNESCO cultural heritage.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 판소리 = traditional art: single singer performs long narrative with drummer. UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage since 2003.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Taekwondo is Korea's representative martial art.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 태권도(跆拳道) = Korea's national martial art, Olympic sport since 2000. Emphasizes kicks. Related: 도장 (training hall), 띠 (belt/rank).

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I went to a Korean medicine clinic because my back hurt.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 한의원 = traditional Korean medicine clinic. Related: 한의학 (Korean traditional medicine), 침(acupuncture), 한약(herbal medicine), 부항(cupping).

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I go to the sauna after exercising.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 사우나 (from Finnish). Many Korean gyms/bathhouses have saunas. Often used interchangeably with 목욕탕, though they differ.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I went to the neighborhood bathhouse and got a scrub.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 목욕탕 = traditional public baths in every neighborhood. 때밀이(body scrub) is signature service. Key part of Korean bathing culture.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I played games at the PC room with friends.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: PC방 = gaming cafes with high-end computers. Very popular in Korea for online games. Usually 24-hour with food/drink service.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: This is ten thousand won.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 만(萬, 10,000) = basic large unit in Korean currency. 만원 bills most commonly used. Approximately 7-8 USD.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example: 요즘 아이돌 콘서트 표가 너무 비싸요.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: K-pop idol concert tickets are so expensive these days.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 아이돌 = members of K-pop groups. Korea's idol culture includes 팬미팅(fan meetings), 응원봉(light sticks), organized fan communities.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: What K-drama are you watching these days?
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: K-드라마 = Korean TV dramas, hugely popular worldwide. Usually 16 episodes. 한국 드라마 is full form. Netflix boosted global popularity.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Korea is famous for its 'hurry hurry' culture.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 빨리빨리 = defining aspect of Korean culture. Everything fast: delivery, internet, construction, service. Reflects rapid modernization, work ethic.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example: 한류 덕분에 한국어를 배우는 사람이 많아요.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Thanks to the Korean Wave, many people are learning Korean.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 한류(韓流) = 한(Korea) + 류(wave/flow). Global popularity of Korean culture: K-pop, K-dramas, Korean food.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: K-pop is popular all around the world.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 케이팝(K-pop) = Korean pop music. Major groups: BTS, BLACKPINK, and many more. Related: 케이팝 팬덤 (K-pop fandom).

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I eat Korean food every day.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 한식(韓食) = 한(Korean) + 식(food). Related: 한식당(Korean restaurant), 양식(Western food), 일식(Japanese), 중식(Chinese).

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Korean traditional medicine considers body balance important.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 한의학(韓醫學) = 한(Korean) + 의학(medicine). Includes 침(acupuncture), 한약(herbal medicine), 부항(cupping). Covered by health insurance.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example: 풍수에 따라 집을 배치하는 사람도 있어요.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Some people arrange their homes according to feng shui.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 풍수(風水) = 풍(wind) + 수(water). 풍수지리 = full term. Historically influenced Korean city planning, grave placement.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: My grandfather is good at calligraphy.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 서예(書藝) = 서(writing) + 예(art). Practiced with 붓(brush) and 먹(ink). Still taught in some Korean schools as cultural education.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Korean pottery is world-famous.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 도자기(陶磁器) = 도(pottery) + 자(porcelain) + 기(vessel). 고려청자(Goryeo celadon) is famous style. 이천 = Korea's pottery capital.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: They sell lots of delicious food at the traditional market.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 전통시장(傳統市場). Famous: 남대문시장, 광장시장, 자갈치시장. Great place to experience Korean food culture.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Korean Buddhism has a very long history.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 불교(佛教) = 불(Buddha) + 교(teaching). Many famous Buddhist temples. 템플스테이(temple stay) popular cultural experience for visitors.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example: 유교 문화가 한국 사회에 큰 영향을 줬어요.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Confucian culture has had a big influence on Korean society.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 유교(儒教) = 유(Confucian) + 교(teaching). 유교적 가치관(Confucian values) influenced Korean education emphasis, respect for elders, family loyalty.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Elders give words of blessing on Lunar New Year.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 덕담(德談) = 덕(virtue) + 담(talk). Elders share encouraging words after 세배. Examples: 건강하거라(be healthy), 공부 잘하거라.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I was invited to a baby's first birthday party.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 돌잔치(첫돌 + 잔치) = celebration of first birthday. Includes 돌잡이 (baby picks objects to predict future). Very elaborate in Korean culture.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: We held a 60th birthday celebration for my father.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 환갑(還甲) = 환(return) + 갑(first). Marks completing 60-year zodiac cycle. Traditionally huge celebration; now less extravagant but still honored.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Bossam is delicious when eaten with kimchi.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 보쌈 = boiled pork belly wrapped in napa cabbage or 깻잎(perilla leaves) with 김치, condiments. Popular dish to share with drinks.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example: 비 오는 날에 막걸리를 마시고 싶어요.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I want to drink makgeolli on a rainy day.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 막걸리 = milky, slightly sweet fermented rice wine. Classic combo: 막걸리와 파전(makgeolli with Korean pancake) on rainy days. Traditional beverage.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example: 이번 달 반상회에서 주차 문제를 이야기했어요.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: We discussed the parking problem at this month's neighborhood meeting.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 반상회(班常會) = 반(group) + 상(regular) + 회(meeting). Regular meetings in apartment complexes to discuss community issues.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: There are many good cafes in our neighborhood.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 동네 = neighborhood. More casual, warm-sounding than 지역(region). Related: 동네 사람(neighbor), 동네 맛집(neighborhood favorite restaurant).

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: An ajumma sells fruit cheaply at the market.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 아줌마 = middle-aged woman. Can sound rude. 아주머니 = polite form. 이모(aunt) = friendlier alternative. Cultural stereotype of assertive Korean women.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: The ajusshi next door is very kind.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 아저씨 = middle-aged man. 삼촌(uncle) = sometimes friendlier alternative. 아저씨 can make younger men feel old. Used for strangers/neighborhood men.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I live in an officetel near my office.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 오피스텔 = 오피스(office) + 호텔(hotel). Korean-style studio apartment in commercial buildings. Popular with single young professionals in cities.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I'm going on a trip to Jeju Island this summer.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 여행(旅行) = noun or verb (여행하다). Related: 여행객 (tourist), 여행 가방 (travel bag), 여행지 (travel destination).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: There are really many places to sightsee in Seoul.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 관광(觀光) = more formal than 구경하다(look around). Related: 관광객 (tourist), 관광지 (tourist spot), 관광 가이드 (tour guide).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I booked a package tour at the travel agency.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 여행사(旅行社) = 여행(travel) + 사(agency). Common pattern: 회사(company), 출판사(publisher), 영화사(film company).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example: 호텔 예약은 미리 하는 게 좋아요.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: It's good to make hotel reservations in advance.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 예약(預約) + 하다 = to reserve/book. Useful word: 미리(in advance). Related: 예약 확인(confirmation), 예약 취소(cancellation).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: You can see the ocean from this hotel.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 호텔 = loanword from English. Korean lodging options: 모텔, 민박(homestay), 펜션(pension/villa), 게스트하우스 (guesthouse).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I met people from many countries at the guesthouse.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 게스트하우스 = popular budget accommodation in Korea, especially in tourist areas like 홍대, 부산.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I stayed at a homestay in the countryside.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 민박(民泊) = traditional Korean lodging, staying in local home. Common in rural/coastal areas. Budget-friendly option.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Check-in is available from 3 PM.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 체크인 = loanword. Related: 체크인하다 (to check in), 체크인 시간 (check-in time).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: What time is check-out?
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 체크아웃 = loanword. Related: 체크아웃하다 (to check out). Usually 11 AM or 12 PM at Korean hotels.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: The room is spacious and clean.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 방(房) = room. Used in compounds: 방값(room rate), 빈방(vacant room), 화장실(bathroom, lit. makeup room).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Please leave the room key at the front desk.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 열쇠 = opens from 열다(open). Modern hotels use 카드키 (card key), keychains, or phone access.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: The luggage is too heavy.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 짐 = luggage/baggage. Related: 짐을 싸다(pack luggage), 짐을 풀다(unpack), 짐 운반.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: The suitcase wheel broke.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 캐리어 = from English 'carrier,' means rolling suitcase specifically. Related: 여행 가방 (travel bag), 수하물 (luggage, formal).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I put my passport in my bag.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 가방 = general word for bag. Types: 핸드백(handbag), 백팩(backpack), 서류 가방(briefcase).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Backpacking is nice because it's freeing.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 배낭(背囊) = backpack. Related: 배낭여행 (backpacking trip), 배낭여행자 (backpacker). Popular among budget travelers.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Please check the passport expiration date.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 여권(旅券) = 여(travel) + 권(document/ticket). Related: 여권 번호(passport number), 유효기간(expiration date).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Do I need a visa to go to Korea?
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 비자 = transliteration of 'visa.' Related: 비자를 받다(get visa), 비자를 신청하다(apply for visa), 비자 면제(visa waiver).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: How long does it take to get to the airport?
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 공항(空港) = 공(sky/air) + 항(harbor/port). Seoul airports: 인천공항(Incheon, international), 김포공항(domestic).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Please show your boarding pass.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 탑승권(搭乘券) = 탑승(boarding) + 권(ticket). Related: 모바일 탑승권(mobile boarding pass), 항공권(airline ticket).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example: 출국 수속은 2시간 전에 하는 게 좋아요.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: It's good to do departure procedures two hours in advance.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 출국(出國) = 출(exit) + 국(country). Related: 출국 수속(departure procedures), 출국 카드. Opposite: 입국(entering country).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I was asked questions at immigration.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 입국(入國) = 입(enter) + 국(country). Related: 입국 심사(immigration inspection), 입국 카드(arrival card).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I went through a luggage inspection at customs.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 세관(稅關) = tax/customs office. Related: 세관 신고서(customs declaration form), 신고할 물건(items to declare).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I bought gifts at the duty-free shop.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 면세점(免稅店) = 면(exempt) + 세(tax) + 점(shop). Korea has large duty-free shops at airports, downtown areas.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Exchange fees are cheaper if you exchange at a bank.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 환전(換錢) + 하다. Related: 환전소 (currency exchange booth), 수수료 (exchange fee).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: What is the exchange rate today?
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 환율(換率) = exchange rate. Related: 환율이 오르다(rate goes up), 환율이 떨어지다(rate drops), 환율 변동.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I got a map at the tourist information center.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 안내소(案內所) = 안내(guidance) + 소(place). Related: 안내하다(to guide), 관광 안내소(tourist info center).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Are there any famous tourist spots nearby?
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 관광지(觀光地) = 관광(sightseeing) + 지(place). Similar: 관광 명소(tourist attraction).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Gyeongbokgung is a representative famous place in Seoul.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 명소(名所) = 명(famous) + 소(place). Related: 관광 명소 (tourist attraction), 숨은 명소 (hidden gem).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Can I take photos here?
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 사진을 찍다 = full form. Related: 셀카 찍다(take a selfie), 기념 사진 (commemorative photo). 찍다 = to take/press/stamp.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I bought a souvenir to give to my friend.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 기념품(記念品) = 기념(commemoration) + 품(item/product). Related: 기념품 가게 (souvenir shop), 지역 특산품.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I found the way using a map app.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 지도 = map. Korean apps: 네이버 지도, 카카오맵 more popular than Google Maps. Related: 지도 앱, 지도 보기.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I planned the travel itinerary.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 일정(日程) = daily schedule/itinerary. Related: 일정을 짜다(plan itinerary), 일정이 빡빡하다(schedule is tight).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I took the city tour bus.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 투어 = loanword from English. Related: 투어를 하다 (do a tour), 당일 투어(day tour), 가이드 투어.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: The guide explained in Korean.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 가이드 = loanword. Related: 관광 가이드(tour guide), 오디오 가이드(audio guide), 가이드 책(guidebook).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: The accommodation is close to the station.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 숙소(宿所) = general term for lodging. Related: 숙소를 잡다(book accommodation), 숙박(lodging).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I'd like to book a single room.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 1인실 = 1인(1 person) + 실(room). Pattern: 2인실(double), 4인실(quad). Used at hotels, guesthouses.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: How much is a double room per night?
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 2인실 = 2인(2 people) + 실(room). Related: 하루에(per day/night), 1박(one night stay), 1박 2일(1 night, 2 days).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: This hotel includes breakfast.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 조식(朝食) = formal 'breakfast.' Casual: 아침(morning) or 아침밥. Related: 조식 뷔페(breakfast buffet).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I swam at the hotel pool.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 수영장(水泳場) = 수영(swimming) + 장(place). Types: 실내 수영장(indoor), 야외 수영장(outdoor), 올림픽 수영장.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I watched the sunrise at the beach.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 해변(海邊) = by the sea. Casual: 바닷가(seaside). Related: 해수욕장(swimming beach, official), 해변 카페.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Korean people really like hiking.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 등산(登山) = 등(climb) + 산(mountain). Hiking extremely popular in Korea at all ages. Related: 등산로(hiking trail), 등산화(hiking boots).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Have you been to the National Museum of Korea?
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 박물관(博物館) = 박물(broad knowledge) + 관(building). Related: 미술관(art museum), 박물관 전시(museum exhibition).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: There are many historic sites in Gyeongju.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 유적지(遺跡地) = 유적(ruins/relics) + 지(place). Gyeongju famous for Silla dynasty ruins. Related: 문화유산(cultural heritage).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Everland is the biggest amusement park in Korea.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 놀이공원 = 놀이(play) + 공원(park). Korea's two major parks: 롯데월드, 에버랜드. Related: 놀이기구(rides).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I relieved my fatigue at the hot spring.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 온천(溫泉) = 온(warm) + 천(spring). Related: 온천욕 (hot spring bathing). Related cultural experience: 찜질방.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I'm going to the ski resort in winter.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 스키장 = 스키(skiing) + 장(place). Popular Korean resorts: 용평, 하이원, 비발디파크. Winter season November-March.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: The campground reservation filled up quickly.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 캠핑장 = 캠핑(camping) + 장(place). 글램핑(glamping) has become very popular in Korea recently.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: A rental car is convenient in Jeju Island.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 렌터카 = 렌트(rental) + 카(car). Also: 렌트카. Related: 차를 빌리다 (rent a car, native Korean expression).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: What transportation is available to the airport?
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 교통편 = 교통(traffic/transport) + 편(way/service). Related: 대중교통(public transportation), 교통수단 (mode of transport).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I bought a round-trip train ticket.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 왕복(往復) = 왕(go) + 복(return). Opposite: 편도(one-way). Used at ticket counters for trains, buses, flights.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: One one-way ticket, please.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 편도(片道) = one way. Opposite: 왕복(round-trip). Used at ticket counters for all transportation.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Can I assign a seat in advance?
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 좌석(座席) = seat. Used for assigned seats on planes, trains, buses, theaters. Related: 좌석 번호(seat number).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: A window seat, please.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 창가(by the window) + 석(seat). Used when booking flights, trains. Opposite: 통로석(aisle seat).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Are there any aisle seats left?
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 통로(aisle/corridor) + 석(seat). Opposite: 창가석(window seat). Used at ticket counters.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Please put your bag in the luggage compartment.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 짐칸 = 짐(luggage) + 칸(compartment/section). On planes, this is the overhead bin.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: You need to fill out the customs declaration form.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 세관신고서 = customs form. Given on international flights before landing. Must declare dutiable items.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: The immigration line is really long.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 입국심사 = 입국(entering country) + 심사(screening/inspection). Happens after landing at airport. Can take time during busy hours.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I'm going to transfer at Incheon Airport.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 환승 = for flight connections and subway/bus transfers. Related: 환승 구역(transit area), 환승 시간(layover time).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: What gate number is it?
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 게이트 = loanword from English. Also: 탑승구(formal Korean). Check your 탑승권 for gate number.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: We depart from Terminal 2.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 터미널 = loanword. Used for airports and bus terminals. Related: 버스 터미널(bus terminal), 제1터미널/제2터미널.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: What time is the departure?
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 출발 시간 = 출발(departure) + 시간(time). Check on your 탑승권(boarding pass). Related: 출발 게이트(departure gate).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: The arrival time has been changed.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 도착 시간 = 도착(arrival) + 시간(time). Related: 예정 도착 시간(estimated arrival time), 지연 도착(delayed arrival).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: The flight was delayed by two hours.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 지연 + 되다 (to be delayed). Check airport screens for 지연 notices. Related: 지연 시간(delay time).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: The flight was cancelled because of a typhoon.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 취소 + 되다 (to be cancelled). Related: 취소 수수료(cancellation fee), 환불(refund), 비행기 결항.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Did you receive the reservation confirmation email?
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 예약 확인 = reservation confirmation. Related: 예약 확인증(confirmation receipt), 확인 이메일.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Hotel prices go up a lot during peak season.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 성수기 = high-demand season. Times: summer vacation, 추석/설날 holidays, school breaks. Opposite: 비수기.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: It's much cheaper if you go during the off-season.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 비수기 = 비(not) + 수(demand) + 기(period). Best time for budget travel. Prices/crowds lower.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: This time I'm going on a package tour.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 패키지 여행 = flights, hotel, tours all included. Popular with Koreans traveling to Europe, Southeast Asia.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I prefer independent travel.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 자유 여행 = you plan everything yourself. Opposite: 패키지 여행. Also: 자유 투어. More flexible, can explore at own pace.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example: 해외여행 가기 전에 여행 보험에 가입했어요.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I signed up for travel insurance before going abroad.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 여행 보험 = 여행(travel) + 보험(insurance). Covers medical emergencies, lost luggage abroad, trip cancellation.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I cook at home on weekends.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 요리(料理 cooking/dish). Related: 요리사(chef), 요리법(recipe), 한국 요리(Korean cuisine). Collocations: 요리를 하다, 밥을 요리하다.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: Boiling ramen is easy.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: Transitive verb: 끓이다(to boil something). Intransitive: 끓다(to boil). Conjugation: 끓여요, 끓였어요. Related: 물을 끓이다(boil water), 스ープ를 끓이다(make soup).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: Please stir-fry the vegetables first.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: Common cooking method in Korean cuisine. Related: 볶음(stir-fry dish), 볶음밥(fried rice), 김치볶음(stir-fried kimchi), 계란 볶음(scrambled eggs).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I grill the meat over charcoal.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: ㅂ irregular verb: 굽다→구워요. Related: 구이(grilled dish), 삼겹살 구이(grilled pork belly), 생선 구이(grilled fish). Essential for Korean BBQ culture.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I steam dumplings and eat them.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: Key cooking technique. Related: 찜(steamed dish), 갈비찜(braised short ribs), 계란찜(steamed egg), 생선찜(steamed fish). Conjugation: 쪄요, 쪘어요.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I deep fry the chicken until it's crispy.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 튀김(fried food). Related: 계란 튀김(fried egg), 야채 튀김(vegetable tempura). 바삭하다 means crispy. Korean fried chicken (치킨) is globally famous.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: Please chop the onion finely.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: Common cutting methods: 잘게 썰다(chop finely), 크게 썰다(cut roughly), 채 썰다(julienne), 동전 썬다(slice into coins). ㄹ irregular verb.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: You mix bibimbap well before eating.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: Related: 비비다(mix, as in 비빔밥), 섞임(mixture). Collocations: 재료를 섞다(mix ingredients), 잘 섞다(mix well).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I add just a little salt.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: Very common cooking verb. Collocations: 소금을 넣다(add salt), 고추를 넣다(add chili), 간장을 넣다(add soy sauce). Regular verb.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I heat it up in the microwave and eat it.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: Related: 따뜻하다(warm), 따뜻하게 데우다(warm up nicely). Collocations: 밥을 데우다(reheat rice), 국을 데우다(warm soup).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: It's too hot, so I cool it down a bit.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: Causative pair: 식다(cool, intransitive) vs 식히다(cool something, transitive). Conjugation: 식혀요, 식혔어요. Related: 식은 밥(cold rice).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: Please taste and check if the seasoning is right.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 맛(taste) + 보다(try/see). Collocations: 음식을 맛보다(taste food), 새로운 요리를 맛보다(try new dish).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I season it with salt.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 간(seasoning level/saltiness). Descriptors: 간이 세다(too salty), 간이 싱겁다(too bland), 간이 딱 맞다(perfectly seasoned).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I found the recipe on YouTube.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: Loanword from English. Korean equivalent: 요리법, 조리법. Collocations: 레시피를 따르다(follow a recipe), 레시피를 찾다(search for a recipe).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: Please prepare the ingredients in advance.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 재료(材料 materials/ingredients). Used for cooking and crafting. Collocations: 재료를 준비하다(prepare ingredients), 신선한 재료(fresh ingredients).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I make the seasoning and marinate the meat.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 양념하다(to season). Related: 양념치킨(seasoned fried chicken), 무양념(unseasoned). Collocation: 양념을 만들다(make seasoning).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I boil water in a big pot.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: Common cookware. Related: 뚝배기(earthenware pot for stews), 냄비 바닥(pot bottom). Collocation: 냄비에 물을 끓이다.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: Coat the frying pan with oil.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: Loanword. 기름을 두르다(coat with oil). Related: 후라이팬(casual form), 스테인리스 팬(stainless pan), 논스틱 팬(non-stick pan).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I chop vegetables on the cutting board.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 나무 도마(wooden board), 플라스틱 도마(plastic board). Collocation: 도마에서 썬다(chop on a board). Traditional Korean kitchens used wooden boards.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I use the knife carefully.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 식칼(kitchen knife), 과도(fruit knife). Descriptors: 칼이 잘 들다(sharp knife), 칼이 무디다(dull knife). Collocation: 칼로 자르다(cut with a knife).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I scoop the soup with a ladle.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 뜨다(to scoop/ladle out). Essential for Korean soup culture. Collocation: 국자로 떠서 먹다(scoop and eat soup).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I flip the pancake with a spatula.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 뒤집다(to flip over). 전(Korean savory pancake): 김치전, 파전, 호박전, etc. Tool essential for Korean cooking.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I put rice in a bowl.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 담다(to fill/put food into). Related: 예쁜 그릇(pretty bowl), 깨진 그릇(broken bowl). Used for serving and eating.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: Please take out a clean plate.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 접시 is flat, 그릇 is deeper. 앞접시(small plate for individual servings). Collocation: 접시를 닦다(wash a plate).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: Please pour water into the cup.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 따르다(to pour). Related: 종이컵(paper cup), 머그컵(mug), 뜨거운 물을 담는 컵. Collocation: 컵에 물을 채우다.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I poured juice into a glass.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 유리(glass material) + 잔(cup). Related: 소주잔(soju glass), 맥주잔(beer glass). Important for Korean drinking culture.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: Please give me some napkins.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: Loanword. Korean restaurants use 휴지(tissue) more commonly. Collocation: 냅킨을 펼치다(unfold napkin).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I wear an apron when cooking.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 앞(front) + 치마(skirt). Protects clothes while cooking. Related: 주방 앞치마(kitchen apron), 앞치마를 입다(put on apron).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I put the cake in the oven.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: Less common in Korean kitchens than Western ones. 전자레인지(microwave) is more standard. Related: 토스터 오븐(toaster oven).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: Please turn on the gas stove.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 불을 켜다(turn on burner), 불을 끄다(turn off). Related: 인덕션(induction cooktop). Important kitchen appliance in Korea.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: These days, many people use induction cooktops.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: Increasingly popular in Korean apartments. 인덕션 전용 냄비(induction-compatible cookware) required. Energy-efficient option.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I cook rice in the rice cooker.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 전기(電氣 electric) + 밥솥(rice pot). 밥을 하다(cook rice). Essential Korean appliance - almost every household has one.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I make fruit juice with a blender.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: Also called 블렌더. 핸드 블렌더(immersion blender). Collocation: 믹서기에 갈다(blend in a mixer).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I put the leftover food in the freezer.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 냉동(冷凍 freezing) + 실(室 room). Related: 냉장실(refrigerator compartment). Preserves food long-term.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: You need to control the heat well.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: Heat level descriptors: 약불(low), 중불(medium), 강불(high). Collocations: 불을 줄이다(reduce heat), 불을 키우다(increase heat).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I simmer it slowly on low heat.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 약(弱 weak). 약불에 졸이다(simmer/reduce on low heat). Used for delicate cooking and slow reduction of sauces.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I stir-fry quickly on high heat.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 강(強 strong). Used for quick stir-frying and bringing water to a boil. Collocation: 강불에 빨리 요리하다.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I cook it on medium heat for about 10 minutes.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 중(中 middle). Most everyday Korean cooking is done on medium heat. Balanced option between speed and control.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: This food tastes really good.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 맛있다(delicious), 맛없다(not tasty). Five basic tastes: 단맛(sweet), 짠맛(salty), 신맛(sour), 쓴맛(bitter), 매운맛(spicy).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: The aroma of sesame oil is really nice.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 향(香 fragrance). 참기름(sesame oil) is a signature Korean cooking ingredient. 향이 나다(to smell of), 향기(scent).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I dress the spinach with sesame oil.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: Classic Korean technique for 나물(seasoned vegetables). Common dishes: 콩나물 무침, 시금치 무침, 도라지 무침.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).english: to pickle; to salt; to marinate
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I salt the napa cabbage.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: Key step in kimchi-making (김치 담그기). Also used for 장아찌(pickled vegetables). Related: 절인 야채(salted vegetables).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: Please mince the garlic finely.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 다진 마늘(minced garlic), 다진 고기(ground meat). Both very common in Korean cooking. Collocation: 마늘을 다지다.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I grind peppers to make chili flakes.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 빻은 후추(ground pepper), 고춧가루(chili powder). Used for grinding spices, beans, or grains.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: If you strain the broth through a sieve, it's cleaner.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 체(sieve) + 에 거르다 is common. Also used for filtering coffee. Related: 국물을 거르다(strain broth).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: This year I made kimchi myself.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 김치를 담그다(to make kimchi) is THE standard phrase. Also 장을 담그다(make fermented sauces). Important in Korean food culture.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I reduce the soy sauce seasoning on low heat.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: Used when reducing liquid to thicken sauce. Related: 조림(braised dish from this verb). Collocation: 양념을 졸이다.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I boil the eggs for 10 minutes.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: Different from 끓이다(to bring liquid to boil). 삶다 focuses on boiling an item in water. Related: 삶은 계란(boiled egg).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I defrost the meat in the fridge.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 해동(thawing). 자연 해동(natural thawing) is safest. Related: 녹이다(to melt/thaw, casual). Collocation: 냉장고에서 해동하다.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I store the leftover food in the fridge.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 냉장 보관(refrigerated), 냉동 보관(frozen), 실온 보관(room temperature). Important for food safety.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: You should throw away milk that's past the expiration date.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 유통(流通 distribution) + 기한(time limit). Korea also uses 소비기한(use-by date). Important for food safety.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: It's convenient if you prepare the ingredients in advance.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 식(food) + 재료(ingredients). More formal than just 재료. Collocation: 신선한 식재료(fresh ingredients).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).english: basic side dishes; make-ahead side dishes
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: I make several basic side dishes on the weekend.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 밑(base/bottom) + 반찬(side dishes). Pre-made sides kept in fridge for the week. Very Korean meal prep concept.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: This broth is really refreshing.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 시원하다(refreshing/satisfying for soup, NOT cold). 국물 요리(soup-based dishes). 국물의 맛(taste of the broth).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example: 양이 너무 많아서 다 못 먹었어요.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: The portion was too big so I couldn't finish it all.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 양이 많다/적다(portion is big/small). Very commonly used at restaurants. Descriptors: 적당한 양(appropriate portion).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: How much is one serving?
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 인분(counter for servings). 2인분, 3인분, 4인분, etc. Many Korean restaurants have 2인분 minimum.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: The food is here, enjoy your meal!
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 드시다(honorific form of 먹다). Said by servers or the person who cooked. Responds to meal: 잘 먹겠습니다(thanks for the meal).

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).english: to be well-seasoned; the seasoning is right
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: The seasoning is just right, it's really delicious.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 간(seasoning). Opposites: 간이 세다(too salty), 간이 싱겁다(too bland). Essential for evaluating Korean food.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example: 불 조절을 잘 해야 안 타요.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: You need to control the heat well so it doesn't burn.
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 불(fire/heat) + 조절(control). Heat levels: 약불, 중불, 강불. Critical skill in Korean cooking.

요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).example_en: Add sesame oil at the end and it's done!
요리 & 부엌 (Cooking & Kitchen).notes: 완성하다(to complete), 완성되다(to be completed). Often used at end of recipe videos. Related: 최종 완성(final finish).

자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).example_en: I lost my wallet. What should I do!
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).notes: Contraction of 어떻게 해요(what should I do). Expresses panic/distress. Related: 어떻게 해(casual), 어떻게 됐어요(what happened).

자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).example_en: They say it'll rain tomorrow. — Really?
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).notes: Gentle expression of surprise. Softer than 진짜요?(really?). Used for acknowledging new information in conversation.

자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).example_en: Studying Korean is fun, right? — That's right.
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).notes: Short for 그렇지요. Used to agree with someone. Very natural agreement phrase in conversation.

자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).example_en: Is this Gangnam Station? — Yes, that's correct.
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).notes: From 맞다(to be correct). Used to confirm facts or agreement. Related: 맞다, 맞게(correctly).

자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).example_en: They say there's no test tomorrow. — Oh really?
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).notes: 진짜(real/really) + 아(interjection). Shows genuine surprise. More emphatic than 그래요.

자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).example_en: I passed the exam! — Awesome!
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).notes: Originally meant 'jackpot.' Very popular modern exclamation for anything impressive. 대박이다, 대박이네.

자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).example_en: Oh my, that must have been hard.
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).notes: Quintessential Korean exclamation expressing sympathy, exhaustion, surprise, or frustration. Interjection specific to Korean culture.

자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).example_en: Whoa, that person got married?
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).notes: Casual/slang popular with younger speakers. Expresses shock or disbelief. Written form of surprise sound.

자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).example_en: Do well on the exam, fighting!
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).notes: Borrowed from English. Used as encouragement everywhere in Korea. Variant: 화이팅. Related: 화이팅하다(cheer on).

자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).example_en: Yes! Tomorrow is a holiday!
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).notes: Exclamation of joy/excitement. Like pumping your fist and saying 'yes!' Very casual and enthusiastic.

자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).example_en: Come on, that's not right.
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).notes: Expresses mild disappointment, disbelief, or playful protest. Interjection common in casual conversation.

자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).example_en: Is this delicious? — Hmm, I'm not sure.
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).notes: Used when hesitating or unsure. Shows you're thinking before answering. Polite way to avoid commitment.

자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).example_en: Why did you come? — Just because.
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).notes: Extremely common filler word. Can mean 'just because,' 'without reason,' or 'as is.' Used everywhere.

자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).example_en: How's that movie? — Not great.
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).notes: 별로(much/particular) used with negatives. Polite way to say something isn't good. Related: 별로 좋지 않아요.

자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).english: it doesn't matter / I don't mind
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).example_en: What do you want to eat? — Anything, I don't mind.
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).notes: 상관(相關 relation/concern) + 없다(absence). Shows flexibility. Related: 상관없이(regardless), 상관하다(to care).

자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).english: it's done / forget it / that's enough
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).example_en: Shall I give you more? — That's enough, thank you.
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).notes: From 되다(to become). Meaning varies by tone: finished, no thanks, forget it. Very versatile.

자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).english: oh I see / ah, so that's how it is
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).example_en: So that's why I was late. — Oh, I see.
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).notes: 구나(exclamatory ending showing new awareness/realization). Shows understanding or realization moment.

자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).example_en: I like coffee. — Me too!
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).notes: 저(I, humble) + 도(also). Casual: 나도(me too). Short and enthusiastic agreement phrase.

자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).english: it can't be helped / there's nothing we can do
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).example: 비가 와서 취소됐어요. — 어쩔 수 없어요.
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).example_en: It was canceled because of rain. — It can't be helped.
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).notes: 어찌할 수 없다(full form). Expresses resigned acceptance. Shows understanding without blame.

자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).example: 이 가격이 백만 원이에요. — 말도 안 돼요!
자주 쓰는 표현 (Common Expressions).example_en: This costs one million won. — No way!
